column1: Stephanie Ann Allen was born in Colorado to Dave and Elizabeth Ann Allen, the middle child of three.<ref name=ncwlife_20190625_FitzSimmons /><ref name=wapo_20190828 /> Her family are farmers.<ref name=wapo_20190828 />

She moved with her mother to [[East Wenatchee, Washington]], where she graduated from [[Eastmont High School]] in 1994.<ref name=ncwlife_20190625_FitzSimmons /><ref name=krem_20190625_Carroll>{{cite web
column3: title=New White House press secretary has ties to East Wenatchee
column9: access-date=November 8, 2019}}</ref> Her mother has since moved to Nebraska, where she is known as Ann Schroder.<ref name=azr_20190626>{{cite news
column11: title=Stephanie Grisham's unlikely path from Arizona politics to White House press secretary

column1: Grisham began voting in Arizona as a registered Democrat in 1997.<ref name=azr_20190626 />
As Stephanie Ann Sommerville, she married Danny Don Marries in Nevada on April 7, 1997.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=Heavy_20190626_McBride>{{cite web
column3: title=Is Stephanie Grisham Married? Learn About Her Ex Husband
column8: access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> They met at [[Mesa State College]] in [[Grand Junction, Colorado]].<ref name=star_20130707>{{cite web
column10: title='We've said our goodbyes:' KOLD anchor posts his pain
column15: access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> They had a son in June 1998, and her husband joined [[KOLD-TV]] as a news anchor in [[Tucson, Arizona]], on the day after their son's first birthday.<ref name=Heavy_20190626_McBride /><ref name=star_20130707 /> They divorced in 2004.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=sentinel_20190626>{{cite news
column17: title=Ex-Tucsonan Grisham named press secretary for President Trump
column26: title=The Untold Truth of Stephanie Gresham

column1: Later in 2004, she subsequently married [[Todd Grisham]], a KOLD sportscaster. They divorced in 2006.<ref name=sentinel_20190626 />
Around 2008, she had a second son.<ref name=Heavy_20190626_McBride/>
Following her divorce(s), Grisham was the spokeswoman for [[American Automobile Association
column4: title=Ex-Tucsonan named spokeswoman for first lady Melania Trump
column9: accessdate=October 17, 2018}}</ref> but was fired within a year after being accused of cheating on expense reports.<ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\">{{cite news
column12: title=Stephanie Grisham's Turbulent Ascent to a Top White House Role
column18: url-status=live }}</ref> Grisham was fired from a subsequent job at ad agency Mindspace over plagiarism charges, copying AAA material verbatim into her client's web page.<ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" />

column1: From 2008 to 2010, Grisham worked as a spokeswoman for the [[Arizona Charter Schools Association]].<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" /> There she met [[Tom Horne]], Arizona's superintendent of public schools.<ref name=azr_20190626 />

Circa 2011 to 2014, Grisham served as spokeswoman for Tom Horne after he was elected Arizona attorney general.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> She witnessed the [[execution of Joseph Wood]] and controversially claimed that the two hour ordeal had been \"quite peaceful\" despite contrary observations.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Arizona killer takes 2 hours to die, fueling lethal-injection debate - Los Angeles Times
column14: title=It's Time to End Our State-Sponsored Barbarism
column22: title=Stephanie Grisham, new White House press secretary, had controversial Arizona career

column1: In 2012, Grisham also worked for [[Mitt Romney]]'s [[Mitt Romney 2012 presidential campaign
column4: title=Single mother from the Valley working for the Trump White House

column1: After Republican [[Mark Brnovich]] defeated Horne in the 2014 GOP primary, Grisham worked as a spokesperson for the [[Arizona House of Representatives]] Republican caucus.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> She revoked the [[Arizona Capitol Times]]'s press credentials hours after their reporting that the House speaker, [[David Gowan]], had traveled at state taxpayers' expense during his campaign for Congress.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=azct_20160408_Small>{{cite web
column3: title=This new background check policy is only the latest retaliation from Gowan's House
column8: accessdate=November 16, 2019}}</ref> Reporters refused to comply, and Gowan rescinded the order.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" />

column1: In September 2015, Grisham worked as a press coordinator for [[Pope Francis's 2015 visit to North America#26 September (New York City, Philadelphia)
column2: Pope Francis's visit to Philadelphia]] as an independent contractor.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Arizona House spokeswoman prepping for the pope

column1: Circa August 2015, Grisham started working as a press aide to [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign
column2: 2016 presidential campaign]].<ref name=\"Fortune06142019\"/><ref name=\"azr_20170119\"/> She helped arrange his campaign stops in Phoenix and around the state and region throughout the primary, a role that quickly expanded to include his rallies around the U.S.<ref name=\"azr_20170119\"/> Grisham was on state payroll until May 2016, when she took an unpaid leave from the Arizona House of Representatives to work on Trump's campaign.<ref name=azct_20190625_Howard /><ref name=\"knau_20161201\">{{cite web
column4: title=Trump Names House PR Person To Staff, Treasurer As Adviser

column1: After his victory, Grisham was named a special adviser for operations and served on Trump's transition team.<ref name=\"azr_20170119\"/><ref name=\"knau_20161201\"/><ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate=October 17, 2018}}</ref> Arizona House speaker David Gowan paid her $19,000 in state salary over an 8-week period while she was serving as a member of the Trump transition team.<ref name=azct_20190625_Howard /><ref name=azct_20170425_Stephenson>{{cite web
column15: title=FLOTUS spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham on state payroll while on Trump's victory tour and transition team

column1: After Trump's January 2017 inauguration, Grisham was named deputy press secretary for [[Sean Spicer]] in the West Wing of the White House.<ref name=\"fox10phoenix\"/><ref name=\"Fortune06142019\"/>

In March 2017, First Lady Melania Trump moved her over to the East Wing.<ref name=\"Fortune06142019\"/><ref name=sentinel_20170327 /> A former White House colleague said that the president regretted losing Grisham to the first lady's office because of Grisham's loyalty and skill at handling the press while acting as his traveling press secretary. During that time, she built relationships with many reporters at events. Despite losing Grisham as part of his own staff, President Trump said he was satisfied that the first lady would \"be in good hands\". Grisham was described by several sources who had worked with her previously as being \"highly competent\" and \"self-aware\"; some suggested that she enjoyed \"trolling the press.\" <ref name=\"Beast\">{{cite web
column3: title=The White House Won't Stop Melania From Contradicting Trump

column1: The [[United States Office of Special Counsel]] stated that Grisham violated the [[Hatch Act of 1939]] following a complaint by Senator [[Tom Carper]]. Grisham was accused of using her official [[Twitter]] account on July 11, 2018, to tweet out Trump's campaign slogan. Violation of the act is not a crime, but a workplace guideline, and the agency responded by sending Grisham a warning letter.<ref name=\"Hatch\">{{cite news
column3: title=Melania Trump's Spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham Violated Hatch Act With 'Make America Great Again' Tweet

column1: In July 2019, Grisham replaced [[Sarah Sanders]] as [[White House Press Secretary
column2: White House press secretary]] and [[White House Communications Director
column5: title=Longtime Trump aide Stephanie Grisham will succeed Sanders as press secretary
column10: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> Grisham's appointment was announced by Melania Trump via [[Twitter]] on June 25, 2019.<ref name=\"Fortune06142019\" /><ref name=cnn_20190625>{{cite news
column12: title=Trump taps Melania Trump's spokeswoman as next White House press secretary
column17: accessdate=September 17, 2019}}</ref> The June 28, 2019 ''Annual Report to Congress on White House Office Personnel'' listed Grisham as \"Assistant to the President and Deputy Chief of Staff for Communications for the First Lady\", with an annual salary of $183,000.00.<ref name=ReportWHpersonnel_20190629>{{cite web
column18: title=Annual Report to Congress on White House Personnel

column1: On September 5, 2019, the ''[[Washington Examiner]]'' published an opinion piece written by Grisham and her deputy [[Hogan Gidley]] entitled, \"The ''Washington Post''{{'}}s lost summer.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column10: accessdate=September 6, 2019}}</ref> The authors asserted the ''Post'' had not reported on several Trump accomplishments that the paper actually did report. In one instance, the piece linked to a ''Post'' story entitled \"Trump becomes first sitting president to set foot into North Korea\" as the authors asserted the paper had not reported the event.<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=Stephanie Grisham Claims ''Washington Post'' Didn't Cover Stories the Paper Actually Did Cover

column1: On September 23, 2019, when asked by the hosts of Fox & Friends if the White House planned to resume its daily press briefing Grisham said \"not right now... I mean, ultimately, if the president decides that it's something we should do, we can do that, but right now he's doing just fine. And to be honest, the briefings have become a lot of theater. And I think that a lot of reporters were doing it to get famous. I mean, yeah, they're writing books now. I mean, they're all getting famous off of this presidency. And so, I think it's great what we're doing now.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House press secretary says daily briefings aren't coming back any time soon

column1: On October 24, 2019, appearing on Fox & Friends, Grisham defended Trump's description of \"Never Trump Republicans\" as \"Human scum\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Never Trumper Republicans, though on respirators with not many left, are in certain ways worse and more dangerous for our Country than the Do Nothing Democrats. Watch out for them, they are human scum!
column9: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref>  When asked if Trump should apologize, Grisham said \"No, no, he shouldn't. The people who are against him and who have been against him and working against his [agenda] since the day they took office are just that. It is horrible that people are working against a president who is delivering results for this country and has been since day one. And, the fact that people continue to try to negate anything he's been trying to do and take away from the good work he's doing on behalf of the American people, they deserve strong language like that.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Press secretary Grisham on Trump's 'human scum' tweet: Those working against him are 'just that'

column1: On October 26, 2019, in response to criticism of President Trump by his former chief of staff Gen. [[John F. Kelly]] (Ret.) Grisham stated: \"I worked with John Kelly, and he was totally unequipped to handle the genius of our President.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House hits back at John Kelly over impeachment remarks

column1: On November 13, 2019, during the testimony of [[William B. Taylor Jr.]], Grisham commented that the [[impeachment inquiry against Donald Trump]] was a \"sham hearing\" that is \"not only boring, it is a colossal waste of taxpayer time & money.\"<ref name=RollCall_20191113>{{cite news
column3: title=White House says Trump 'too busy' to watch 'boring' impeachment hearing
column10: title=Full Video and Analysis of Day 1 of Impeachment Hearing Testimony

column1: That same month, Grisham claimed that Obama administration officials had left \"you will fail\" notes for the incoming Trump administration officials. Numerous Obama administration officials rejected the claim. Grisham ultimately retracted her assertion.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Trump press secretary backtracks claim Obama officials left 'You will fail' notes

column1: In December 2019, Grisham defended President Trump's implication that former congressman [[John Dingell]] was in hell. She described Trump as a \"counter-puncher\" who was \"under attack.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House defends Trump as 'counter-puncher' after he suggests late Michigan congressman in hell
column8: title=White House defends Trump's attack on dead lawmaker John Dingell

column1: On April 7, 2020, it was announced that Grisham left her role as White House Press Secretary and returned to the East Wing to serve as Melania Trump's chief of staff,<ref name=\"CNN-Out\" /> effective that same day.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Grisham leaves role as White House press secretary

column1: As of March 11, 2020, Grisham had not conducted a formal press briefing in 365 days.<ref name=cnn_20200311>{{cite news
column3: title=Make sure to remember this appalling 1-year anniversary
column11: title=Stephanie Grisham: Trump's Press Secretary Who Doesn't Meet the Press
column18: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> However, she appeared on Fox News, Fox Business Network, [[One America News Network]], and the Sinclair Broadcast Group many times during the same period.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /><ref>{{cite news
column20: title=White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham has yet to hold a briefing with reporters, but finds time for Fox News
column25: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' devoted two prime-time segments in one week to question whether taxpayers should pay her $183,000 salary,<ref name=nyt_20200110 /> and her hypocrisy.<ref name=cnn_20200110>{{cite news
column27: title=Cooper to WH press sec.: Your secret is safe with us
column33: access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref> \"Miss Grisham has gone from 'we are human beings' to 'they are human scum.' ... It's actually really kind of sad....\"<ref name=cnn_20200107>{{cite news
column35: title=Cooper calls out White House over lack of press briefings
column43: title=Anderson Cooper Nails Hypocrisy Of Trump Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham
column50: title=Anderson Cooper doubled down in his feud with White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham, calling her statements 'kind of sad'
column55: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> Her \"unintentionally ironic and deeply hypocritical\" social media statements and infrequent televised interviews \"appear meant to defend the president but actually point out the president's own failings.\"<ref name=cnn_20200110 /><ref>{{cite web
column57: title=Anderson Cooper Has A Theory About Stephanie Grisham Secretly Working Against Trump
column62: access-date=January 12, 2020}}</ref>  Margaret Sullivan has commented in the ''[[Washington Post]]'' that Grisham \"may hold the title but she's not doing the job\".<ref name=wapo_20200111>{{cite newspaper
column64: title=Stephanie Grisham is not the worst-ever White House press secretary. Here's why.

column1: Authors [[Don Winslow]] and [[Stephen King]] pledged to donate $100,000 each to charity after Grisham held a 60-minute briefing answering questions from the White House press corps.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /> Also, 13 former White House and military press secretaries from three administrations before Trump published a letter calling for the restoration of press briefings.<ref name=wapo_20200111 /><ref name=nyt_20200110 /><ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Why America needs to hear from its government
column6: access-date=January 10, 2020}}</ref> The press briefings never occurred.<ref>{{Cite news
column10: title=Stephanie Grisham out as White House press secretary after eight months during which she held no regular news briefings
column16: first2=closeAnne GearanWhite House reporterEmailEmailBioBioFollowFollowJosh Dawsey closeJosh DawseyReporter covering the White

column1: On January 9, 2013, Grisham was pulled over for speeding in [[Gilbert, Arizona
column2: Gilbert]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]]. The officer observed Grisham's signs of intoxication, and she failed a field sobriety test. Grisham denied consuming any alcohol, but said she had taken a Xanax 90 minutes earlier and a Zoloft the prior night. A blood test revealed Grisham's blood alcohol content to be .105 percent, which is above the .08 legal limit in Arizona. She also was found to be driving on a suspended license since August 2012 for failure to answer a traffic citation. In August 2014, Grisham accepted a plea bargain agreement that reduced the charge to misdemeanor reckless driving, plus two years of probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Like So Many Of His Associates, Donald Trump's New Press Secretary Has Posed For Some Mug Shots
column8: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> She returned to court twice for failure to pay the $779 in fines and failure to complete a [[Mothers Against Drunk Driving]] program.<ref name=azr_20190626 />

column1: Shortly after midnight, December 5, 2015, Grisham was arrested again in [[Phoenix, Arizona
column2: Phoenix]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]], for driving without her headlights and suspicion of [[driving under the influence]]; thus violating her probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> Grisham failed to appear at her court hearing on January 19, 2016,<ref name=azr_20190626 /> whereupon the judge issued a warrant for her arrest.<ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" /> Afterwards, Grisham pleaded guilty.  In July 2016, she was ordered into a treatment program and to pay nearly $1,600 in court costs and fines.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" />

column10: accessdate=September 6, 2019}}</ref> The authors asserted the ''Post'' had not reported on several Trump accomplishments that the paper actually did report. In one instance, the piece linked to a ''Post'' story entitled \"Trump becomes first sitting president to set foot into North Korea\" as the authors asserted the paper had not reported the event.<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=Stephanie Grisham Claims ''Washington Post'' Didn't Cover Stories the Paper Actually Did Cover

column1: On September 23, 2019, when asked by the hosts of Fox & Friends if the White House planned to resume its daily press briefing Grisham said \"not right now... I mean, ultimately, if the president decides that it's something we should do, we can do that, but right now he's doing just fine. And to be honest, the briefings have become a lot of theater. And I think that a lot of reporters were doing it to get famous. I mean, yeah, they're writing books now. I mean, they're all getting famous off of this presidency. And so, I think it's great what we're doing now.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House press secretary says daily briefings aren't coming back any time soon

column1: On October 24, 2019, appearing on Fox & Friends, Grisham defended Trump's description of \"Never Trump Republicans\" as \"Human scum\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Never Trumper Republicans, though on respirators with not many left, are in certain ways worse and more dangerous for our Country than the Do Nothing Democrats. Watch out for them, they are human scum!
column9: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref>  When asked if Trump should apologize, Grisham said \"No, no, he shouldn't. The people who are against him and who have been against him and working against his [agenda] since the day they took office are just that. It is horrible that people are working against a president who is delivering results for this country and has been since day one. And, the fact that people continue to try to negate anything he's been trying to do and take away from the good work he's doing on behalf of the American people, they deserve strong language like that.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Press secretary Grisham on Trump's 'human scum' tweet: Those working against him are 'just that'

column1: On October 26, 2019, in response to criticism of President Trump by his former chief of staff Gen. [[John F. Kelly]] (Ret.) Grisham stated: \"I worked with John Kelly, and he was totally unequipped to handle the genius of our President.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House hits back at John Kelly over impeachment remarks

column1: On November 13, 2019, during the testimony of [[William B. Taylor Jr.]], Grisham commented that the [[impeachment inquiry against Donald Trump]] was a \"sham hearing\" that is \"not only boring, it is a colossal waste of taxpayer time & money.\"<ref name=RollCall_20191113>{{cite news
column3: title=White House says Trump 'too busy' to watch 'boring' impeachment hearing
column10: title=Full Video and Analysis of Day 1 of Impeachment Hearing Testimony

column1: That same month, Grisham claimed that Obama administration officials had left \"you will fail\" notes for the incoming Trump administration officials. Numerous Obama administration officials rejected the claim. Grisham ultimately retracted her assertion.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Trump press secretary backtracks claim Obama officials left 'You will fail' notes

column1: In December 2019, Grisham defended President Trump's implication that former congressman [[John Dingell]] was in hell. She described Trump as a \"counter-puncher\" who was \"under attack.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=White House defends Trump as 'counter-puncher' after he suggests late Michigan congressman in hell
column8: title=White House defends Trump's attack on dead lawmaker John Dingell

column5: title=Grisham leaves role as White House press secretary

column1: On January 9, 2013, Grisham was pulled over for speeding in [[Gilbert, Arizona
column2: Gilbert]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]]. The officer observed Grisham's signs of intoxication and she failed a field sobriety test. Grisham denied consuming any alcohol, but said she had taken a Xanax 90 minutes earlier and a Zoloft the prior night. A blood test revealed Grisham's blood alcohol content to be .105 percent, which is above the .08 legal limit in Arizona. She also was found to be driving on a suspended license since August 2012 for failure to answer a traffic citation. In August 2014, Grisham accepted a plea bargain agreement that reduced the charge to misdemeanor reckless driving, plus two years of probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Like So Many Of His Associates, Donald Trump's New Press Secretary Has Posed For Some Mug Shots
column8: access-date=November 15, 2019}}</ref> She returned to court twice for failure to pay the $779 in fines, and failure to complete a [[Mothers Against Drunk Driving]] program.<ref name=azr_20190626 />

column1: Shortly after midnight, December 5, 2015, Grisham was arrested again in [[Phoenix, Arizona
column2: Phoenix]], [[Maricopa County, Arizona]], for driving without her headlights and suspicion of [[driving under the influence]]; thus violating her probation.<ref name=azr_20190626 /> Grisham failed to appear at her court hearing on January 19, 2016,<ref name=azr_20190626 /> whereupon the judge issued a warrant for her arrest.<ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" /> Grisham pleaded guilty, and in July 2016 was ordered into a treatment program and to pay nearly $1,600 in court costs and fines.<ref name=azr_20190626 /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190625\" /><ref name=\"NYTimes_20190822\" /><ref name=\"tsg_20190828\" />

column1: The Antonov An-225 was an enlargement of the successful [[Antonov An-124 Ruslan
column2: Antonov An-124]] that was initially developed for transporting the [[Buran (spacecraft)
column3: Buran]] [[spaceplane]]. The only An-225 airplane was completed in 1988. After successfully fulfilling its Soviet military missions, it was [[Aircraft boneyard
column4: mothballed]] for eight years. It was then refurbished and re-introduced, and is in commercial operation with [[Antonov Airlines]] carrying oversized payloads.<ref name=\"FlightglobalWorldsLargestAircraftAn-225EmergesToSetNewLiftRecord\"/> The airlifter holds the absolute [[world records]] for an airlifted single-item payload of {{convert

column1: The second An-225 was partially built during the late 1980s for the Soviet space program. Following the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 and the cancellation of the Buran space program, the lone operational An-225 was placed in storage in 1994.<ref>[http://www.airliners.net/aircraft-data/stats.main?id=389 Antonov An-225 Mriya]. Airliners.net.</ref><ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=World's biggest unfinished plane hidden in a hangar
column9: language=en}}</ref> The six [[Ivchenko-Progress]] engines were removed for use on An-124s, and the second uncompleted An-225 airframe was also stored. When it became clear that a cargoliner bigger than the An-124 was needed, the first An-225 was re-engined and put back into service.<ref name=\"ramAn225\"/><ref name=mf>\"[http://www.militaryfactory.com/aircraft/detail.asp?aircraft_id=58 Antonov An-225 Mriya (Cossack) Heavy Lift Strategic Long-Range Transport]\" ''Military Factory'', 23 August 2012. Retrieved: 6 September 2012.</ref>

column1: By 2000, the need for additional An-225 capacity had become apparent, so the decision was made in September 2006 to complete the second An-225. The second airframe was scheduled for completion around 2008,<ref>[http://www.aviationexplorer.com/Antonov_AN-225.html Antonov An-225 Mriya Aircraft History, Facts and Pictures]. Aviationexplorer</ref> then delayed. By August 2009, the aircraft had not been completed and work had been abandoned.<ref name=\"FlightglobalWorldsLargestAircraftAn-225EmergesToSetNewLiftRecord\">{{cite news

column2: An-124]], the An-225 has fuselage barrel extensions added fore and aft of the wings. The wings also received root extensions to increase span. The wings are [[Anhedral (aeronautics)
column6: title=Aerospaceweb.org {{!}} Ask Us - Wing Twist and Dihedral
column9: date=2 December 2001}}</ref><ref name=mf/> The [[flight control surfaces]] are controlled via [[fly-by-wire]] and triple-redundant hydraulics.<ref name=\"ramAn225\"/><ref>{{cite web
column12: website=www.copybook.com}}</ref> Two more [[Progress D-18T]] [[turbofan]] engines were added to the new [[wing root]]s, bringing the total to six. An increased-capacity [[landing gear]] system with 32 wheels was designed, some of which are steerable, enabling the aircraft to turn within a {{convert
column17: -wide}} runway. Like its An-124 predecessor, the An-225 has nose gear designed to \"kneel\" so cargo can be more easily loaded and unloaded.<ref name=\"ramAn225\"/> Unlike the An-124, which has a rear cargo door and ramp, the An-225 design left these off to save weight, and the [[empennage]] design was changed from a single [[vertical stabilizer]] to a [[twin tail]] with an oversized, swept-back [[Stabilizer (aircraft)
column18: horizontal stabilizer]]. The twin tail was essential to enable the plane to carry large, heavy external loads that would disturb the [[aerodynamics
column19: airflow]] around a conventional tail. Unlike the An-124, the An-225 was not intended for [[Airlift#Tactical airlift
column20: tactical airlifting]] and is not designed for [[STOL

column1: During the last years of the [[Soviet space program]], the An-225 was employed as the prime method of transporting the [[Buran (spacecraft)

In the late 1980s, the Soviet government was looking for a way to generate revenue from its military assets. In 1989, the Antonov Design Bureau set up a holding company as a heavy airlift shipping corporation under the name \"[[Antonov Airlines]]\", based in [[Kiev]], Ukraine and operating from [[London Luton Airport]] in partnership with [[Air Foyle HeavyLift]].<ref name=\"antonov\"/><ref name=\"goleta\">{{cite web

The company began operations with a fleet of four An-124-100s and three [[Antonov An-12]]s, but a need for aircraft larger than the An-124 became apparent in the late 1990s. In response, the original An-225 was re-engined, modified for heavy cargo transport, and placed back in service under the management of Antonov Airlines.
On 23 May 2001, the An-225 received its type certificate from the Interstate Aviation Committee Aviation Register (IAC AR).<ref>{{cite web

column1: The An-225 attracts a high degree of public interest, so much that it has managed to attain a global following due to its size and its uniqueness. People frequently visit airports to see its scheduled arrivals and departures, such as in [[Perth]], Australia in May 2016 when a crowd of more than 50,000 people gathered at [[Perth Airport]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Antonov An-225 Mriya touches down in WA amid traffic chaos near Perth Airport

column1: The type's first flight in commercial service departed from [[Stuttgart]], Germany on 3 January 2002, and flew to [[Thumrait, Oman]] with 216,000 prepared meals for American military personnel based in the region. This vast number of ready meals was transported on 375 pallets and weighed 187.5 tons.<ref name=airfoyle2>{{cite web

The An-225 has since become the workhorse of the Antonov Airlines fleet, transporting objects once thought impossible to move by air, such as 150-tonne generators. It has become an asset to international relief organizations for its ability to quickly transport huge quantities of emergency supplies during disaster relief operations.<ref name=\"aircraft info\">{{cite web

The An-225 has been contracted by the Canadian and U.S. governments to transport military supplies to the Middle East in support of coalition forces.<ref name=\"aircraft info\"/> An example of the cost of shipping cargo by An-225 was over 2 million [[Danish krone

column3: Billund]], Denmark to Kazakhstan in 2004.<ref name=\"steelcon\">[http://www.steelcon.com/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/News/Steelcon__News_GB.pdf Steelcon News] {{webarchive

column4: reporting name]]: '''Cossack''') is a [[strategic airlift]] [[cargo aircraft]] that was designed by the [[Antonov
column5: Antonov Design Bureau]] in the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic
column6: Ukrainian SSR]] within the [[Soviet Union]] during the 1980s. It is powered by six [[turbofan]] engines and is the [[list of large aircraft
column7: heaviest aircraft ever built]], with a [[maximum takeoff weight]] of {{convert
column10: ST+LT}}. It also has the largest [[wingspan]] of any aircraft in operational service. The single example built has the [[Ukraine
column11: Ukrainian]] civil registration '''UR-82060'''. A second airframe with a slightly different configuration<ref name=\"flightrevival\">{{cite web
column15: title= An-225 revival proposed in new Antonov-China pact
column18: access-date= 15 December 2016}}</ref> was partially built. Its construction was halted in 1994<ref name=\"flightrevival\"/> because of lack of funding and interest, but revived briefly in 2009, bringing it to 60–70% completion.<ref name=\"ainrevival\">{{cite web
column22: title= Antonov Sells Dormant An-225 Heavylifter Program to China
column25: access-date= 15 December 2016}}</ref> On 30 August 2016, Antonov agreed to complete the second airframe for [[Airspace Industry Corporation of China]] (not to be confused with the [[Aviation Industry Corporation of China]]) as a prelude to commencing series production.<ref name=\"popscirevival\">{{cite web
column31: title=China Will Resurrect The World's Largest Plane
column34: access-date=15 December 2016 }}. Note that the company name is wrong. The official press release has the right name: [https://archive.is/20160901093407/http://www.antonov.com/news/478]</ref>

column1: The Antonov An-225 was an enlargement of the successful [[Antonov An-124 Ruslan
column2: Antonov An-124]] that was initially developed for transporting the [[Buran (spacecraft)
column3: Buran]] [[spaceplane]]. The only An-225 airplane was completed in 1988. After successfully fulfilling its Soviet military missions, it was [[Aircraft boneyard
column4: mothballed]] for eight years. It was then refurbished and re-introduced, and is in commercial operation with [[Antonov Airlines]] carrying oversized payloads.<ref name=\"FlightglobalWorldsLargestAircraftAn-225EmergesToSetNewLiftRecord\"/> The airlifter holds the absolute [[world records]] for an airlifted single-item payload of {{convert
column9: lk=on}},<ref name= \"Armenia1\" /><ref name= \"Armenia2\" /> and an airlifted total payload of {{convert
column14: title=Payload record in the official FAI database
column18: archivedate=12 June 2013  }}</ref><ref name=\"ramAn225\">[http://ram-home.com/ram-old/an-225.html An-225 (An-225-100) \"Мрiя\"]. ''Russian Aviation Museum'', 20 October 2001. Retrieved: 31 October 2010.</ref> It has also transported a payload of {{convert
column21: abbr=on}} on a commercial flight.<ref name=\"FlightglobalAn-225SetsNewRecordForPayload\">{{cite news
column22: title=An-225 sets new record for payload

column1: [[File:Antonov An-225 with Soviet space shuttle Buran on top.jpeg
The Antonov An-225 was designed to airlift the [[Energia]] rocket's [[Zenit (rocket family)#Energia booster
column3: ''Buran'']] orbiter for the [[Soviet space program]]. It was developed as a replacement for the [[Myasishchev VM-T]]. The An-225's original mission and objectives are almost identical to that of the United States' [[Shuttle Carrier Aircraft]].<ref name=\"goebel\">{{cite web

column1: The second An-225 was partially built during the late 1980s for the Soviet space program. Following the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 and the cancellation of the Buran space program, the lone operational An-225 was placed in storage in 1994.<ref>[http://www.airliners.net/aircraft-data/stats.main?id=389 Antonov An-225 Mriya]. Airliners.net.</ref><ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=World's biggest unfinished plane hidden in a hangar
column9: language=en}}</ref> The six [[Ivchenko-Progress]] engines were removed for use on An-124s, and the second uncompleted An-225 airframe was also stored. When it became clear that a cargoliner bigger than the An-124 was needed, the first An-225 was re-engined and put back into service.<ref name=\"ramAn225\"/><ref name=mf>\"[http://www.militaryfactory.com/aircraft/detail.asp?aircraft_id=58 Antonov An-225 Mriya (Cossack) Heavy Lift Strategic Long-Range Transport]\" ''Military Factory'', 23 August 2012. Retrieved: 6 September 2012.</ref>

column1: By 2000, the need for additional An-225 capacity had become apparent, so the decision was made in September 2006 to complete the second An-225. The second airframe was scheduled for completion around 2008,<ref>[http://www.aviationexplorer.com/Antonov_AN-225.html Antonov An-225 Mriya Aircraft History, Facts and Pictures]. Aviationexplorer</ref> then delayed. By August 2009, the aircraft had not been completed and work had been abandoned.<ref name=\"FlightglobalWorldsLargestAircraftAn-225EmergesToSetNewLiftRecord\">{{cite news
column2: title=World's largest aircraft, An-225, emerges to set new lift record
column9: archivedate=20 August 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.buran-energia.com/blog/2008/12/22/the-mriya-2-2/lang/en/ The Mriya 2: Pictures]. Buran-energia.com</ref> In May 2011, the Antonov CEO is reported to have said that the completion of a second An-225 Mriya transport aircraft with a carrying capacity of 250 tons requires at least $300 million, but if the financing is provided, its completion could be achieved in three years.<ref name=\"$300m needed for completion of An-225 transport\">{{cite web
column15: accessdate=16 September 2016}}</ref> According to different sources, the second aircraft is 60–70% complete.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Ukraine may finish the construction of second An-225 Mriya transport aircraft – News – Russian Aviation

column2: An-124]], the An-225 has fuselage barrel extensions added fore and aft of the wings. The wings also received root extensions to increase span. The wings are [[Anhedral (aeronautics)
column6: title=Aerospaceweb.org {{!}} Ask Us - Wing Twist and Dihedral
column9: date=2 December 2001}}</ref><ref name=mf/> The [[flight control surfaces]] are controlled via [[fly-by-wire]] and triple-redundant hydraulics.<ref name=\"ramAn225\"/><ref>{{cite web
column12: website=www.copybook.com}}</ref> Two more [[Progress D-18T]] [[turbofan]] engines were added to the new [[wing root]]s, bringing the total to six. An increased-capacity [[landing gear]] system with 32 wheels was designed, some of which are steerable, enabling the aircraft to turn within a {{convert
column17: -wide}} runway. Like its An-124 predecessor, the An-225 has nose gear designed to \"kneel\" so cargo can be more easily loaded and unloaded.<ref name=\"ramAn225\"/> Unlike the An-124, which has a rear cargo door and ramp, the An-225 design left these off to save weight, and the [[empennage]] design was changed from a single [[vertical stabilizer]] to a [[twin tail]] with an oversized, swept-back [[Stabilizer (aircraft)
column18: horizontal stabilizer]]. The twin tail was essential to enable the plane to carry large, heavy external loads that would disturb the [[aerodynamics
column19: airflow]] around a conventional tail. Unlike the An-124, the An-225 was not intended for [[Airlift#Tactical airlift
column20: tactical airlifting]] and is not designed for [[STOL

column1: During the last years of the [[Soviet space program]], the An-225 was employed as the prime method of transporting the [[Buran (spacecraft)

In the late 1980s, the Soviet government was looking for a way to generate revenue from its military assets. In 1989, the Antonov Design Bureau set up a holding company as a heavy airlift shipping corporation under the name \"[[Antonov Airlines]]\", based in [[Kiev]], Ukraine and operating from [[London Luton Airport]] in partnership with [[Air Foyle HeavyLift]].<ref name=\"antonov\"/><ref name=\"goleta\">{{cite web

The company began operations with a fleet of four An-124-100s and three [[Antonov An-12]]s, but a need for aircraft larger than the An-124 became apparent in the late 1990s. In response, the original An-225 was re-engined, modified for heavy cargo transport, and placed back in service under the management of Antonov Airlines.
On 23 May 2001, the An-225 received its type certificate from the Interstate Aviation Committee Aviation Register (IAC AR).<ref>{{cite web

column1: The type's first flight in commercial service departed from [[Stuttgart]], Germany on 3 January 2002, and flew to [[Thumrait, Oman]] with 216,000 prepared meals for American military personnel based in the region. This vast number of ready meals was transported on 375 pallets and weighed 187.5 tons.<ref name=airfoyle2>{{cite web

The An-225 has since become the workhorse of the Antonov Airlines fleet, transporting objects once thought impossible to move by air, such as 150-tonne generators. It has become an asset to international relief organizations for its ability to quickly transport huge quantities of emergency supplies during disaster relief operations.<ref name=\"aircraft info\">{{cite web

The An-225 has been contracted by the Canadian and U.S. governments to transport military supplies to the Middle East in support of coalition forces.<ref name=\"aircraft info\"/> An example of the cost of shipping cargo by An-225 was over 2 million [[Danish krone

column1: The '''Battle of Bautzen''' (or '''Battle of Budziszyn''', April 1945) was one of the last battles of the [[Eastern Front (WWII)
column2: Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. It was fought on the extreme southern flank of the [[Battle of the Oder–Neisse#Spremberg-Torgau Offensive
column3: Spremberg-Torgau Offensive]], seeing days of pitched street fighting between forces of the [[Polish Second Army]] under elements of the Soviet [[52nd Army (Soviet Union)
column8: none}} on one side and elements of German [[Army Group Center]] in the form of the remnants of the [[4th Panzer Army

column1: The battle took place during [[Ivan Konev]]'s [[1st Ukrainian Front]]'s push toward Berlin, which was part of the larger Soviet [[Battle of Berlin
column2: Berlin Offensive]]. The battle was fought in the town of [[Bautzen]] ({{lang-pl
column3: Budziszyn}}) and the rural areas to the northeast situated primarily along the Bautzen–[[Niesky]] line. Major combat began on 21 April 1945 and continued until 26 April although isolated engagements continued to take place until 30 April. The Polish Second Army under [[Karol Świerczewski]] suffered heavy losses, but, with the aid of Soviet reinforcements, prevented the German forces from breaking through to their rear.

column1: After the battle both sides claimed victory and modern views as to who won the battle remain contradictory. Because the war was almost over and the battle had no strategic impact on the ongoing Battle of Berlin, German historiography has focused more on its tactical aspects. The German operation successfully recaptured Bautzen and its surroundings, which were held until the end of the war.

In the last months of World War II, the Polish Second Army, under General Karol Świerczewski, took part in the Soviet drive on Berlin.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/> Part of Marshal Ivan Konev's 1st Ukrainian Front, the Poles operated in the centre of the front, flanked on the right by the 5th Guards Army and on the left by the [[7th Mechanized Corps (Soviet Union)
column2: 7th Mechanized Corps]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> Opposing these forces was the [[4th Panzer Army]] under General [[Fritz-Hubert Gräser]], of Field Marshal [[Ferdinand Schörner]]'s [[Army Group Center]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/>

column1: On 17 April, the Polish Second Army breached German defenses on the rivers [[Weißer Schöps
column2: Weisser Schöps]]<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> and [[Neisse]]. Their pursuit of retreating German forces toward [[Dresden]] threatened to cut off additional forces in the [[Muskau Park
column3: Muskauer Forst]] region.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-128\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> On 18 and 19 April elements of the Second Army (the 8th Infantry Division and [[1st Armoured Corps (Poland)
column4: 1st Armored Corps]]) engaged the Germans in the south and pushed them back while the remaining units (5th, 7th, 9th and 10th infantry divisions) drove on to Dresden, gaining bridgeheads on the River [[Spree]] north of Bautzen and destroying German forces in the Muskauer Forst.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> The following day Soviet units of the 7th Mechanized Corps captured parts of Bautzen and secured the line south of [[Niesky]], taking [[Weißenberg]] and trapping several German formations.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=Ahlfen207208/>

column1: Świerczewski decided to prioritize the taking of Dresden over securing his southern flank, deviating from the plan he was given by Konev.<ref name=zw/> Meanwhile, Schörner was concentrating his units (the \"Görlitz Group\") in the [[Görlitz]] (Zgorzelec) and [[Reichenbach (Oberlausitz)
column2: Reichenbach]] region, and planned to launch a counteroffensive at the southern flank of the Polish Army. His aim was to stop the 1st Front's advance and break through to Berlin to relieve the trapped [[9th Army (Wehrmacht)
column3: 9th Army]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The Germans were pinning their hopes on the idea that the Soviets might be fended off long enough for the city to be surrendered to the Western Allies.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/> The concentration of Schörner's units went unnoticed by Soviet and Polish reconnaissance.<ref name=zw/>

column1: German forces were composed of elements of the 4th Panzer Army and commanded by the headquarters for the ''Grossdeutschland'' and 57th Armored Corps.  For the battle, the Germans had two armored divisions (the [[20th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)
column3: Hermann Göring]]''), two mechanized divisions (the ''[[Panzergrenadier Division Brandenburg
column5: Hermann Göring 2]]''), an infantry division (the [[17th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)
column6: 17th]]) as well as an infantry division battle group (the remnants of the 545th Volksgrenadier Division).   This force counted some 50,000 soldiers, 300 tanks, and 600 guns.<ref name=Grzelak272/> The supply train of the [[10th SS Panzer Division Frundsberg
column7: 10th SS Panzer Division]] was also present near Bautzen.<ref name=LexikonWehrmacht/>{{Ref label

column1: The Polish Second Army consisted of five infantry divisions: ([[Polish 5th Infantry Division
column6: 10th]], the 1st Armored Corps, and smaller units), about 84,000–90,000 men, and 500 tanks.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Many of them were new recruits inexperienced in combat, incorporated from the recently retaken Polish territories.<ref name=zw/> The quality of the officer corps has also been questioned.<ref name=zw/> One of the major problems facing the People's Army was lack of a qualified cadre; a 1944 estimate showed that the army had one officer for each 1,200 soldiers.<ref name=\"Michta1990\"/> Many of the officers in the Polish Army were Soviet officers of Polish descent.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/>

column1: Overall, the German units were less numerous than the Polish forces, their equipment worn and supplies inferior. Polish sources describe the Germans as more experienced, however the German sources accentuate their mixed structure of experienced soldiers and inexperienced recruits of ''[[Hitlerjugend]]'' and ''[[Volkssturm]]'' units.<ref name=Eberhardt/><ref name=zw/>

column1: On 21 April, a gap had formed between the Polish infantry units (8th and 9th infantry divisions) and the 1st Armored Corps pushing towards Dresden, and the Polish units which were securing the Muskauer Forst region.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The 7th and 10th infantry divisions were engaged near Neisse and the 5th Infantry Division and the 16th Tank Brigade were in transit in between those two groups.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The Polish units were stretched over a line of {{convert
column4: sp=us}}.<ref name=zw/> The Germans took the opportunity to push into this gap.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The battle started on 21 April.<ref name=\"zw\"/> In the west, the 20th Panzer Division started its drive on Bautzen, while in the east the 17th Infantry Division  advanced on Niesky and Weißenberg, freeing trapped German troops on its way.<ref name=Ahlfen208/> The Germans drove between the Polish Second Army and the [[52nd Army (Soviet Union)
column11: sp=us}} west of Görlitz, sweeping the Soviet units of the [[48th Rifle Corps]], and driving towards [[Spremberg]].<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Major General [[M. K. Puteiko]], commander of the 52nd Army's [[254th Rifle Division]] of the [[73rd Rifle Corps]] was mortally wounded around Bautzen.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998\"/> At first, Polish general Świerczewski continued with his attempt to take Dresden, which contributed to the growing chaos in the Polish forces, as many communication lines were cut.<ref name=zw/>

column1: The Germans succeeded in linking up with the remnants of their forces in the Muskauer Forst, and throwing the local Polish and Soviet forces into chaos.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The Polish Second Army lost cohesion and split into four groups.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Several units of the Polish Second Army found themselves surrounded.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> In particular, the Polish 5th Infantry Division and 16th Tank Brigade were struck in the rear, suffering severe losses.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The headquarters of the 5th Division, defended only by sapper and training battalions, came under attack.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/> The command group managed to break through to the 16th Tank Brigade, but that unit itself was almost annihilated at [[Förstgen]] (Forsiegen), losing over 90 percent of its personnel; out of 1,300 soldiers, only about 100 survived.<ref name=zw/> The commanding general of the Polish 5th Infantry Division, [[Aleksander Waszkiewicz]], was killed.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/> In the village of Niederkaina, today a part of Bautzen, between 196 and 300 captured German members of the ''Volkssturm'' were locked in a barn which was set on fire by retreating Polish or Soviet troops.<ref name=\"Eberhardt\"/><ref name=kiS/><ref name=ba/>

By 23 April the German breakthrough reached the [[Schwarzer Schöps]] River in the east, and [[Lohsa]], [[Oppitz]] and [[Grossdubrau]] in the west. The main body of the German force was located in the forested region around Lohsa.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The Germans continued their push toward [[Königswartha]] and [[Hoyerswerda]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

Eventually, Świerczewski halted his force's advance on Dresden, and ordered it to pull back and secure the breach.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-132\"/> On 22 April he ordered the 1st Armored Corps to change direction, retreat from Dresden and support the centre. The 8th Infantry Division was also recalled; however, the 9th remained near Dresden. For a while Świerczewski was out of communication with his superiors, including Marshal Konev.<ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Konev also sent his chief of staff, General [[Ivan Yefimovich Petrov]], and his chief of operations, General [[Vladimir Ivanovich Kostylev]], to look at the situation.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Petrov managed to re-establish communications, and left Kostylev in charge.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/> Świerczewski was briefly relieved of his command for incompetence.<ref name=\"zw\"/> To stabilize the situation, Konev ordered eight divisions from the Ukrainian Front to reinforce the Polish positions.<ref name=zw/> The [[14th Guards Rifle Division
column3: 95th Guards Rifle Divisions]], as well as the [[4th Guards Kantemirovskaya Tank Division
column4: 4th Guards Tank Corps]], were ordered to attack toward [[Kamenz]], Königswartha and [[Sdier]] to stop the Germans from advancing further north.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\" /> The [[2nd Air Army]] was also assigned to this theater.<ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/>

column1: Meanwhile, the German advance to the southeast of Bautzen was successful. The Soviet [[294th Rifle Division]] was encircled at Weißenberg by the ''Brandenburg'' Division.<ref name=Ahlfen208/> In its subsequent breakout on 24 April, large parts of the 294th Division were destroyed. At the same time at Bautzen the 20th Panzer Division was able to make contact with the trapped units in the town from the south. Bronikowski then lost no time and immediately ordered an attack into Bautzen. Coordinating with the trapped troops, he was able to break into the town. A hastily assembled Polish counterattack was not successful and most of Bautzen was then recaptured after several days of bloody [[house-to-house fighting
column2: house-to-house combat]]. Several remaining pockets of resistance in the town were cleared during the next days.<ref name=Ahlfen208209/><ref name=B199942-46/> Outside the town the German advance stalled, as their troops were running low on fuel supplies.<ref name=Eberhardt/><ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> The recapture of Bautzen was one of the last successful German tactical victories on the Eastern Front.<ref name=\"WilliamsonAndrew2003\"/>

column1: By 25 April, Polish units were able to stabilize a defense on the line Kamenz–[[Kuckau]]–north Bautzen–Spree–[[Spreewiese]]–[[Kreba-Neudorf
column2: Heideanger]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> On that day, [[Hitler]] congratulated Schörner on his \"victory\".<ref name=\"Mcateer2009\"/> The Polish 7th and 10th infantry divisions were ordered to advance toward Sdier-Heideanger.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The 7th and 10th Polish infantry divisions slowly advanced, with the 10th reaching north of [[Uhyst
column3: Spreefurt]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> With the Soviet units on their right flank they also secured a road to Königswartha.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/>

column1: The 9th Division found itself alone at the spearhead of the abandoned Polish push towards Dresden. It received orders to retreat on 26 April.<ref name=as/> Attempting to withdraw quickly and to form back with the main forces, it was intercepted by the Germans and sustained heavy losses.<ref name=zw/> The units were moving with insufficient security, on the assumption that the line of retreat was safe; at the same time the Germans captured Polish orders with details of their planned withdrawal routes.<ref name=zw/> Coordination between the units was also lacking.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> 26th Infantry Regiment from the 9th Division took very heavy casualties (75 percent) in the \"valley of death\" around [[Panschwitz-Kuckau]] and [[Crostwitz]].<ref name=zw/> A Polish [[military hospital]] convoy from the same division was ambushed near [[Horka, Saxony
column2: Horka]], with [[War crimes of the Wehrmacht
column3: most of its personnel and wounded executed]] (about 300 casualties). There was only one survivor, chaplain Jan Rdzanek.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"GrzelakStańczyk1993\"/> The division commander, Colonel [[Aleksander Łaski]], was taken captive.<ref name=zw/><ref name=zw/> As a result of these losses, the 9th Division ceased to be an effective force; the remaining personnel were merged into the Soviet [[19th Guards Rifle Division]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

column1: According to some sources, 26 April marks the end of this battle, although less severe and isolated clashes in that region continued until 30 April.<ref name=zw/> Other sources note that heavy fighting still took place on 27 April, and that the German advance was only completely halted by 28 April.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> By the end of the month, the Polish Second Army and the Soviet forces had repelled the German attack, forming a line toward Kamenz–[[Doberschütz]]–[[Dauban]], and was preparing to launch an offensive toward [[Prague]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/>

Both sides suffered heavy casualties.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> The Polish casualties were particularly severe.<ref name=zw/> In a relatively short time the Polish Second Army lost more than 22 percent of its personnel and 57 percent of its tanks and armored vehicles (about 200 total).<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Official estimates claimed about 18,000 casualties (including almost 5,000 dead).<ref name=zw/> Some other estimates give the Polish casualties as up to 25,000.<ref name=zw/> According to Polish historian [[Zbigniew Wawer]], this was the most bloody battle that the [[Polish Army]] had been involved in since the [[battle of Bzura]] in 1939.<ref name=zw/>

German casualties were significant, but less than the Polish and Soviet ones; contemporary Polish sources estimated German losses at 6,500 personnel, which is now seen as an inflated estimate.<ref name=zw/> The German forces failed in their objective of breaking through the 1st Ukrainian Front and coming to the aid of Berlin.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-138\"/> They managed, however, to inflict very serious casualties on the local Polish and Soviet units and stopped the Polish drive on Dresden (it was still in German hands at the time of the German capitulation on May 9).<ref name=zw/> The successful recapture of Bautzen, Weißenberg and surroundings is called one of the last successful German armored counterattacks of the war. Bautzen and surroundings stayed in German hands until [[German Instrument of Surrender
column2: Germany's capitulation]]. Although the battle had no strategic impact on the battle raging  in Berlin, it allowed most of the participating German units as well as numerous refugees from the east to escape to the west, surrendering to the Western Allies.<ref name=zw/><ref name=B199942-46/><ref name=Ahlfen209/>

column1: Despite the heavy Polish casualties, or possibly because of them, the battle has been largely neglected in Polish [[historiography]].<ref name=\"zw\"/> During the period of the [[People's Republic of Poland]] it was portrayed merely as a difficult but victorious battle.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-138\"/> However, since the [[fall of communism]] modern Polish historians have been much more critical of Świerczewski's command, blaming his drive on Dresden for the near destruction of the Polish force.<ref name=zw/> Świerczewski's lack of competence, according to some sources, included commanding the battle while drunk.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Piecuch1997\"/> He was briefly relieved of command by Marshal Konev,<ref name=zw/> but due to the backing of the Soviet high command (most likely the [[NKVD]]) he not only retained his position but all controversies were hushed up, and after the war was hailed as a hero.<ref name=zw/> The actions of other Polish officers have also been questioned, such as the 9th Infantry Division commander's decision to advance without sufficient reconnaissance and escort.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

In modern Poland, the battle's outcome is seen as a victory, if a very costly one, for the Polish and Soviet troops.<ref name=zw/> As noted by historians such as Wawer and Komorowski, despite the heavy casualties, the Polish–Soviet frontline was not seriously breached, and thus the German offensive was a failure.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

column4: none}} Wawer incorrectly identifies this formation as the [[5th Guards Tank Army]], which was near the Baltic coast at the time and subordinated to the 2nd Belorussian Front.<ref name=zw/> Komornicki correctly identifies the formation as the [[5th Guards Army (Soviet Union)

none}} Wawer and Solak assert that the 2nd SS Panzer Division was also present in the battle. This is an incorrect assertion as the 2nd SS Division fought in Hungary and Austria from January 1945 until the end of the war.<ref name=T145/> The 21st Panzer Division has also been mentioned in connection with this battle, but the 21st had already moved north as part of reinforcements provided by the 4th Panzer Army to the 9th Army. By the time the Battle of Bautzen had begun, both the 21st Panzer Division and the 10th SS Panzer Division (minus its supply train) were committed to support the 9th Army and both were encircled in the [[Battle of Halbe
column5: Halbe Pocket]]. The assessments of Polish historian Kormonicki,<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> German general von Ahlfen, and Polish historian Grzelak all support the order of battle not including the 21st and 10th SS Divisions.

column1: The '''Battle of Bautzen''' (or '''Battle of Budziszyn''', April 1945) was one of the last battles of the [[Eastern Front (WWII)
column2: Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. It was fought on the extreme southern flank of the [[Battle of the Oder–Neisse#Spremberg-Torgau Offensive
column3: Spremberg-Torgau Offensive]], seeing days of pitched street fighting between forces of the [[Polish Second Army]] under elements of the Soviet [[52nd Army (Soviet Union)
column8: none}} on one side and elements of German [[Army Group Center]] in the form of the remnants of the [[4th Panzer Army

column1: The battle took place during [[Ivan Konev]]'s [[1st Ukrainian Front]]'s push toward Berlin, which was part of the larger Soviet [[Battle of Berlin
column2: Berlin Offensive]]. The battle was fought in the town of [[Bautzen]] ({{lang-pl
column3: Budziszyn}}) and the rural areas to the northeast situated primarily along the Bautzen–[[Niesky]] line. Major combat began on 21 April 1945 and continued until 26 April although isolated engagements continued to take place until 30 April. The Polish Second Army under [[Karol Świerczewski]] suffered heavy losses, but, with the aid of Soviet reinforcements, prevented the German forces from breaking through to their rear.

column1: After the battle both sides claimed victory and modern views as to who won the battle remain contradictory. Because the war was almost over and the battle had no strategic impact on the ongoing Battle of Berlin, German historiography has focused more on its tactical aspects. The German operation successfully recaptured Bautzen and its surroundings, which were held until the end of the war.

In the last months of World War II, the Polish Second Army, under General Karol Świerczewski, took part in the Soviet drive on Berlin.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/> Part of Marshal Ivan Konev's 1st Ukrainian Front, the Poles operated in the centre of the front, flanked on the right by the 5th Guards Army and on the left by the [[7th Mechanized Corps (Soviet Union)
column2: 7th Mechanized Corps]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> Opposing these forces was the [[4th Panzer Army]] under General [[Fritz-Hubert Gräser]], of Field Marshal [[Ferdinand Schörner]]'s [[Army Group Center]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/>

column1: On 17 April, the Polish Second Army breached German defenses on the rivers [[Weißer Schöps
column2: Weisser Schöps]]<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> and [[Neisse]]. Their pursuit of retreating German forces toward [[Dresden]] threatened to cut off additional forces in the [[Muskau Park
column3: Muskauer Forst]] region.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-128\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> On 18 and 19 April elements of the Second Army (the 8th Infantry Division and [[1st Armoured Corps (Poland)
column4: 1st Armored Corps]]) engaged the Germans in the south and pushed them back while the remaining units (5th, 7th, 9th and 10th infantry divisions) drove on to Dresden, gaining bridgeheads on the River [[Spree]] north of Bautzen and destroying German forces in the Muskauer Forst.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> The following day Soviet units of the 7th Mechanized Corps captured parts of Bautzen and secured the line south of [[Niesky]], taking [[Weißenberg]] and trapping several German formations.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=Ahlfen207208/>

column1: Świerczewski decided to prioritize the taking of Dresden over securing his southern flank, deviating from the plan he was given by Konev.<ref name=zw/> Meanwhile, Schörner was concentrating his units (the \"Görlitz Group\") in the [[Görlitz]] (Zgorzelec) and [[Reichenbach (Oberlausitz)
column2: Reichenbach]] region, and planned to launch a counteroffensive at the southern flank of the Polish Army. His aim was to stop the 1st Front's advance and break through to Berlin to relieve the trapped [[9th Army (Wehrmacht)
column3: 9th Army]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The Germans were pinning their hopes on the idea that the Soviets might be fended off long enough for the city to be surrendered to the Western Allies.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/> The concentration of Schörner's units went unnoticed by Soviet and Polish reconnaissance.<ref name=zw/>

column1: German forces were composed of elements of the 4th Panzer Army and commanded by the headquarters for the ''Grossdeutschland'' and 57th Armored Corps.  For the battle, the Germans had two armored divisions (the [[20th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)
column3: Hermann Göring]]''), two mechanized divisions (the ''[[Panzergrenadier Division Brandenburg
column5: Hermann Göring 2]]''), an infantry division (the [[17th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)
column6: 17th]]) as well as an infantry division battle group (the remnants of the 545th Volksgrenadier Division).   This force counted some 50,000 soldiers, 300 tanks, and 600 guns.<ref name=Grzelak272/> The supply train of the [[10th SS Panzer Division Frundsberg
column7: 10th SS Panzer Division]] was also present near Bautzen.<ref name=LexikonWehrmacht/>{{Ref label

column1: The Polish Second Army consisted of five infantry divisions: ([[Polish 5th Infantry Division
column6: 10th]], the 1st Armored Corps, and smaller units), about 84,000–90,000 men, and 500 tanks.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Many of them were new recruits inexperienced in combat, incorporated from the recently retaken Polish territories.<ref name=zw/> The quality of the officer corps has also been questioned.<ref name=zw/> One of the major problems facing the People's Army was lack of a qualified cadre; a 1944 estimate showed that the army had one officer for each 1,200 soldiers.<ref name=\"Michta1990\"/> Many of the officers in the Polish Army were Soviet officers of Polish descent.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/>

column1: Overall, the German units were less numerous than the Polish forces, their equipment worn and supplies inferior. Polish sources describe the Germans as more experienced, however the German sources accentuate their mixed structure of experienced soldiers and inexperienced recruits of ''[[Hitlerjugend]]'' and ''[[Volkssturm]]'' units.<ref name=Eberhardt/><ref name=zw/>

column1: The 9th Division found itself alone at the spearhead of the abandoned Polish push towards Dresden. It received orders to retreat on 26 April.<ref name=as/> Attempting to withdraw quickly and to form back with the main forces, it was intercepted by the Germans and sustained heavy losses.<ref name=zw/> The units were moving with insufficient security, on the assumption that the line of retreat was safe; at the same time the Germans captured Polish orders with details of their planned withdrawal routes.<ref name=zw/> Coordination between the units was also lacking.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> 26th Infantry Regiment from the 9th Division took very heavy casualties (75 percent) in the \"valley of death\" around [[Panschwitz-Kuckau]] and [[Crostwitz]].<ref name=zw/> A Polish [[military hospital]] convoy from the same division was ambushed near [[Horka, Saxony
column2: Horka]], with [[War crimes of the Wehrmacht
column3: most of its personnel and wounded executed]] (about 300 casualties). There was only one survivor, chaplain Jan Rdzanek.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"GrzelakStańczyk1993\"/> The division commander, Colonel [[Aleksander Łaski]], was taken captive.<ref name=zw/><ref name=zw/> As a result of these losses, the 9th Division ceased to be an effective force; the remaining personnel were merged into the Soviet [[19th Guards Rifle Division]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

column1: According to some sources, 26 April marks the end of this battle, although less severe and isolated clashes in that region continued until 30 April.<ref name=zw/> Other sources note that heavy fighting still took place on 27 April, and that the German advance was only completely halted by 28 April.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> By the end of the month, the Polish Second Army and the Soviet forces had repelled the German attack, forming a line toward Kamenz–[[Doberschütz]]–[[Dauban]], and was preparing to launch an offensive toward [[Prague]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/>

Both sides suffered heavy casualties.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> The Polish casualties were particularly severe.<ref name=zw/> In a relatively short time the Polish Second Army lost more than 22 percent of its personnel and 57 percent of its tanks and armored vehicles (about 200 total).<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Official estimates claimed about 18,000 casualties (including almost 5,000 dead).<ref name=zw/> Some other estimates give the Polish casualties as up to 25,000.<ref name=zw/> According to Polish historian [[Zbigniew Wawer]], this was the most bloody battle that the [[Polish Army]] had been involved in since the [[battle of Bzura]] in 1939.<ref name=zw/>

German casualties were significant, but less than the Polish and Soviet ones; contemporary Polish sources estimated German losses at 6,500 personnel, which is now seen as an inflated estimate.<ref name=zw/> The German forces failed in their objective of breaking through the 1st Ukrainian Front and coming to the aid of Berlin.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-138\"/> They managed, however, to inflict very serious casualties on the local Polish and Soviet units and stopped the Polish drive on Dresden (it was still in German hands at the time of the German capitulation on May 9).<ref name=zw/> The successful recapture of Bautzen, Weißenberg and surroundings is called one of the last successful German armored counterattacks of the war. Bautzen and surroundings stayed in German hands until [[German Instrument of Surrender
column2: Germany's capitulation]]. Although the battle had no strategic impact on the battle raging  in Berlin, it allowed most of the participating German units as well as numerous refugees from the east to escape to the west, surrendering to the Western Allies.<ref name=zw/><ref name=B199942-46/><ref name=Ahlfen209/>

column1: Despite the heavy Polish casualties, or possibly because of them, the battle has been largely neglected in Polish [[historiography]].<ref name=\"zw\"/> During the period of the [[People's Republic of Poland]] it was portrayed merely as a difficult but victorious battle.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-138\"/> However, since the [[fall of communism]] modern Polish historians have been much more critical of Świerczewski's command, blaming his drive on Dresden for the near destruction of the Polish force.<ref name=zw/> Świerczewski's lack of competence, according to some sources, included commanding the battle while drunk.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Piecuch1997\"/> He was briefly relieved of command by Marshal Konev,<ref name=zw/> but due to the backing of the Soviet high command (most likely the [[NKVD]]) he not only retained his position but all controversies were hushed up, and after the war was hailed as a hero.<ref name=zw/> The actions of other Polish officers have also been questioned, such as the 9th Infantry Division commander's decision to advance without sufficient reconnaissance and escort.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

In modern Poland, the battle's outcome is seen as a victory, if a very costly one, for the Polish and Soviet troops.<ref name=zw/> As noted by historians such as Wawer and Komorowski, despite the heavy casualties, the Polish–Soviet frontline was not seriously breached, and thus the German offensive was a failure.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

column4: none}} Wawer incorrectly identifies this formation as the [[5th Guards Tank Army]], which was near the Baltic coast at the time and subordinated to the 2nd Belorussian Front.<ref name=zw/> Komornicki correctly identifies the formation as the [[5th Guards Army (Soviet Union)

none}} Wawer and Solak assert that the 2nd SS Panzer Division was also present in the battle. By the time the Battle of Bautzen had begun, both the 21st Panzer Division and the 10th SS Panzer Division (minus its supply train) were committed to support the 9th Army and both were encircled in the [[Battle of Halbe
column5: Halbe Pocket]]. The assessments of Polish historian Kormonicki,<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> German general von Ahlfen, and Polish historian Grzelak all support the order of battle not including the 21st and 10th SS Divisions.

column1: The '''Battle of Bautzen''' (or '''Battle of Budziszyn''', April 1945) was one of the last battles of the [[Eastern Front (WWII)
column2: Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. It was fought on the extreme southern flank of the [[Battle of the Oder–Neisse#Spremberg-Torgau Offensive
column3: Spremberg-Torgau Offensive]], seeing days of pitched street fighting between forces of the [[Polish Second Army]] under elements of the Soviet [[52nd Army (Soviet Union)
column8: none}} on one side and elements of German [[Army Group Center]] in the form of the remnants of the [[4th Panzer Army

column1: The battle took place during [[Ivan Konev]]'s [[1st Ukrainian Front]]'s push toward Berlin, which was part of the larger Soviet [[Battle of Berlin
column2: Berlin Offensive]]. The battle was fought in the town of [[Bautzen]] ({{lang-pl
column3: Budziszyn}}) and the rural areas to the northeast situated primarily along the Bautzen–[[Niesky]] line. Major combat began on 21 April 1945 and continued until 26 April although isolated engagements continued to take place until 30 April. The Polish Second Army under [[Karol Świerczewski]] suffered heavy losses, but, with the aid of Soviet reinforcements, prevented the German forces from breaking through to their rear.

column1: After the battle both sides claimed victory and modern views as to who won the battle remain contradictory. Because the war was almost over and the battle had no strategic impact on the ongoing Battle of Berlin, German historiography has focused more on its tactical aspects. The German operation successfully recaptured Bautzen and its surroundings, which were held until the end of the war.

In the last months of World War II, the Polish Second Army, under General Karol Świerczewski, took part in the Soviet drive on Berlin.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/> Part of Marshal Ivan Konev's 1st Ukrainian Front, the Poles operated in the centre of the front, flanked on the right by the 5th Guards Army and on the left by the [[7th Mechanized Corps (Soviet Union)
column2: 7th Mechanized Corps]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> Opposing these forces was the [[4th Panzer Army]] under General [[Fritz-Hubert Gräser]], of Field Marshal [[Ferdinand Schörner]]'s [[Army Group Center]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/>

column1: On 17 April, the Polish Second Army breached German defenses on the rivers [[Weißer Schöps
column2: Weisser Schöps]]<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> and [[Neisse]]. Their pursuit of retreating German forces toward [[Dresden]] threatened to cut off additional forces in the [[Muskau Park
column3: Muskauer Forst]] region.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-128\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> On 18 and 19 April elements of the Second Army (the 8th Infantry Division and [[1st Armoured Corps (Poland)
column4: 1st Armored Corps]]) engaged the Germans in the south and pushed them back while the remaining units (5th, 7th, 9th and 10th infantry divisions) drove on to Dresden, gaining bridgeheads on the River [[Spree]] north of Bautzen and destroying German forces in the Muskauer Forst.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> The following day Soviet units of the 7th Mechanized Corps captured parts of Bautzen and secured the line south of [[Niesky]], taking [[Weißenberg]] and trapping several German formations.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=Ahlfen207208/>

column1: Świerczewski decided to prioritize the taking of Dresden over securing his southern flank, deviating from the plan he was given by Konev.<ref name=zw/> Meanwhile, Schörner was concentrating his units (the \"Görlitz Group\") in the [[Görlitz]] (Zgorzelec) and [[Reichenbach (Oberlausitz)
column2: Reichenbach]] region, and planned to launch a counteroffensive at the southern flank of the Polish Army. His aim was to stop the 1st Front's advance and break through to Berlin to relieve the trapped [[9th Army (Wehrmacht)
column3: 9th Army]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The Germans were pinning their hopes on the idea that the Soviets might be fended off long enough for the city to be surrendered to the Western Allies.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/> The concentration of Schörner's units went unnoticed by Soviet and Polish reconnaissance.<ref name=zw/>

column1: German forces were composed of elements of the 4th Panzer Army and commanded by the headquarters for the ''Grossdeutschland'' and 57th Armored Corps.  For the battle, the Germans had two armored divisions (the [[20th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)
column3: Hermann Göring]]''), two mechanized divisions (the ''[[Panzergrenadier Division Brandenburg
column5: Hermann Göring 2]]''), an infantry division (the [[17th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)
column6: 17th]]) as well as an infantry division battle group (the remnants of the 545th Volksgrenadier Division).   This force counted some 50,000 soldiers, 300 tanks, and 600 guns.<ref name=Grzelak272/> The supply train of the [[10th SS Panzer Division Frundsberg
column7: 10th SS Panzer Division]] was also present near Bautzen.<ref name=LexikonWehrmacht/>{{Ref label

column1: The Polish Second Army consisted of five infantry divisions: ([[Polish 5th Infantry Division
column6: 10th]], the 1st Armored Corps, and smaller units), about 84,000–90,000 men, and 500 tanks.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Many of them were new recruits inexperienced in combat, incorporated from the recently retaken Polish territories.<ref name=zw/> The quality of the officer corps has also been questioned.<ref name=zw/> One of the major problems facing the People's Army was lack of a qualified cadre; a 1944 estimate showed that the army had one officer for each 1,200 soldiers.<ref name=\"Michta1990\"/> Many of the officers in the Polish Army were Soviet officers of Polish descent.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/>

column1: Overall, the German units were less numerous than the Polish forces, their equipment worn and supplies inferior. Polish sources describe the Germans as more experienced, however the German sources accentuate their mixed structure of experienced soldiers and inexperienced recruits of ''[[Hitlerjugend]]'' and ''[[Volkssturm]]'' units.<ref name=Eberhardt/><ref name=zw/>
