column1: On 21 April, a gap had formed between the Polish infantry units (8th and 9th infantry divisions) and the 1st Armored Corps pushing towards Dresden, and the Polish units which were securing the Muskauer Forst region.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The 7th and 10th infantry divisions were engaged near Neisse and the 5th Infantry Division and the 16th Tank Brigade were in transit in between those two groups.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The Polish units were stretched over a line of {{convert
column4: sp=us}}.<ref name=zw/> The Germans took the opportunity to push into this gap.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The battle started on 21 April.<ref name=\"zw\"/> In the west, the 20th Panzer Division started its drive on Bautzen, while in the east the 17th Infantry Division  advanced on Niesky and Weißenberg, freeing trapped German troops on its way.<ref name=Ahlfen208/> The Germans drove between the Polish Second Army and the [[52nd Army (Soviet Union)
column11: sp=us}} west of Görlitz, sweeping the Soviet units of the [[48th Rifle Corps]], and driving towards [[Spremberg]].<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Major General [[M. K. Puteiko]], commander of the 52nd Army's [[254th Rifle Division]] of the [[73rd Rifle Corps]] was mortally wounded around Bautzen.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998\"/> At first, Polish general Świerczewski continued with his attempt to take Dresden, which contributed to the growing chaos in the Polish forces, as many communication lines were cut.<ref name=zw/>

column1: The Germans succeeded in linking up with the remnants of their forces in the Muskauer Forst, and throwing the local Polish and Soviet forces into chaos.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The Polish Second Army lost cohesion and split into four groups.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Several units of the Polish Second Army found themselves surrounded.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> In particular, the Polish 5th Infantry Division and 16th Tank Brigade were struck in the rear, suffering severe losses.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The headquarters of the 5th Division, defended only by sapper and training battalions, came under attack.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/> The command group managed to break through to the 16th Tank Brigade, but that unit itself was almost annihilated at [[Förstgen]] (Forsiegen), losing over 90 percent of its personnel; out of 1,300 soldiers, only about 100 survived.<ref name=zw/> The commanding general of the Polish 5th Infantry Division, [[Aleksander Waszkiewicz]], was killed.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/> In the village of Niederkaina, today a part of Bautzen, between 196 and 300 captured German members of the ''Volkssturm'' were locked in a barn which was set on fire by retreating Polish or Soviet troops.<ref name=\"Eberhardt\"/><ref name=kiS/><ref name=ba/>

By 23 April the German breakthrough reached the [[Schwarzer Schöps]] River in the east, and [[Lohsa]], [[Oppitz]] and [[Grossdubrau]] in the west. The main body of the German force was located in the forested region around Lohsa.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The Germans continued their push toward [[Königswartha]] and [[Hoyerswerda]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

Eventually, Świerczewski halted his force's advance on Dresden, and ordered it to pull back and secure the breach.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-132\"/> On 22 April he ordered the 1st Armored Corps to change direction, retreat from Dresden and support the centre. The 8th Infantry Division was also recalled; however, the 9th remained near Dresden. For a while Świerczewski was out of communication with his superiors, including Marshal Konev.<ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Konev also sent his chief of staff, General [[Ivan Yefimovich Petrov]], and his chief of operations, General [[Vladimir Ivanovich Kostylev]], to look at the situation.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Petrov managed to re-establish communications, and left Kostylev in charge.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/> Świerczewski was briefly relieved of his command for incompetence.<ref name=\"zw\"/> To stabilize the situation, Konev ordered eight divisions from the Ukrainian Front to reinforce the Polish positions.<ref name=zw/> The [[14th Guards Rifle Division
column3: 95th Guards Rifle Divisions]], as well as the [[4th Guards Kantemirovskaya Tank Division
column4: 4th Guards Tank Corps]], were ordered to attack toward [[Kamenz]], Königswartha and [[Sdier]] to stop the Germans from advancing further north.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\" /> The [[2nd Air Army]] was also assigned to this theater.<ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/>

column1: Meanwhile, the German advance to the southeast of Bautzen was successful. The Soviet [[294th Rifle Division]] was encircled at Weißenberg by the ''Brandenburg'' Division.<ref name=Ahlfen208/> In its subsequent breakout on 24 April, large parts of the 294th Division were destroyed. At the same time at Bautzen the 20th Panzer Division was able to make contact with the trapped units in the town from the south. Bronikowski then lost no time and immediately ordered an attack into Bautzen. Coordinating with the trapped troops, he was able to break into the town. A hastily assembled Polish counterattack was not successful and most of Bautzen was then recaptured after several days of bloody [[house-to-house fighting
column2: house-to-house combat]]. Several remaining pockets of resistance in the town were cleared during the next days.<ref name=Ahlfen208209/><ref name=B199942-46/> Outside the town the German advance stalled, as their troops were running low on fuel supplies.<ref name=Eberhardt/><ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> The recapture of Bautzen was one of the last successful German tactical victories on the Eastern Front.<ref name=\"WilliamsonAndrew2003\"/>

column1: By 25 April, Polish units were able to stabilize a defense on the line Kamenz–[[Kuckau]]–north Bautzen–Spree–[[Spreewiese]]–[[Kreba-Neudorf
column2: Heideanger]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> On that day, [[Hitler]] congratulated Schörner on his \"victory\".<ref name=\"Mcateer2009\"/> The Polish 7th and 10th infantry divisions were ordered to advance toward Sdier-Heideanger.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The 7th and 10th Polish infantry divisions slowly advanced, with the 10th reaching north of [[Uhyst
column3: Spreefurt]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> With the Soviet units on their right flank they also secured a road to Königswartha.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/>

column1: The '''Battle of Bautzen''' (or '''Battle of Budziszyn''', April 1945) was one of the last battles of the [[Eastern Front (WWII)
column2: Eastern Front]] during [[World War II]]. It was fought on the extreme southern flank of the [[Battle of the Oder–Neisse#Spremberg-Torgau Offensive
column3: Spremberg-Torgau Offensive]], seeing days of pitched street fighting between forces of the [[Polish Second Army]] under elements of the Soviet [[52nd Army (Soviet Union)
column8: none}} on one side and elements of German [[Army Group Center]] in the form of the remnants of the [[4th Panzer Army

column1: The battle took place during [[Ivan Konev]]'s [[1st Ukrainian Front]]'s push toward Berlin, which was part of the larger Soviet [[Battle of Berlin
column2: Berlin Offensive]]. The battle was fought in the town of [[Bautzen]] ({{lang-pl
column3: Budziszyn}}) and the rural areas to the northeast situated primarily along the Bautzen–[[Niesky]] line. Major combat began on 21 April 1945 and continued until 26 April although isolated engagements continued to take place until 30 April. The Polish Second Army under [[Karol Świerczewski]] suffered heavy losses, but, with the aid of Soviet reinforcements, prevented the German forces from breaking through to their rear.

column1: After the battle both sides claimed victory and modern views as to who won the battle remain contradictory. Because the war was almost over and the battle had no strategic impact on the ongoing Battle of Berlin, German historiography has focused more on its tactical aspects. The German operation successfully recaptured Bautzen and its surroundings, which were held until the end of the war.

In the last months of World War II, the Polish Second Army, under General Karol Świerczewski, took part in the Soviet drive on Berlin.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/> Part of Marshal Ivan Konev's 1st Ukrainian Front, the Poles operated in the centre of the front, flanked on the right by the 5th Guards Army and on the left by the [[7th Mechanized Corps (Soviet Union)
column2: 7th Mechanized Corps]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> Opposing these forces was the [[4th Panzer Army]] under General [[Fritz-Hubert Gräser]], of Field Marshal [[Ferdinand Schörner]]'s [[Army Group Center]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-122\"/>

column1: On 17 April, the Polish Second Army breached German defenses on the rivers [[Weißer Schöps
column2: Weisser Schöps]]<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-123\"/> and [[Neisse]]. Their pursuit of retreating German forces toward [[Dresden]] threatened to cut off additional forces in the [[Muskau Park
column3: Muskauer Forst]] region.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-128\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> On 18 and 19 April elements of the Second Army (the 8th Infantry Division and [[1st Armoured Corps (Poland)
column4: 1st Armored Corps]]) engaged the Germans in the south and pushed them back while the remaining units (5th, 7th, 9th and 10th infantry divisions) drove on to Dresden, gaining bridgeheads on the River [[Spree]] north of Bautzen and destroying German forces in the Muskauer Forst.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> The following day Soviet units of the 7th Mechanized Corps captured parts of Bautzen and secured the line south of [[Niesky]], taking [[Weißenberg]] and trapping several German formations.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=Ahlfen207208/>

column1: Świerczewski decided to prioritize the taking of Dresden over securing his southern flank, deviating from the plan he was given by Konev.<ref name=zw/> Meanwhile, Schörner was concentrating his units (the \"Görlitz Group\") in the [[Görlitz]] (Zgorzelec) and [[Reichenbach (Oberlausitz)
column2: Reichenbach]] region, and planned to launch a counteroffensive at the southern flank of the Polish Army. His aim was to stop the 1st Front's advance and break through to Berlin to relieve the trapped [[9th Army (Wehrmacht)
column3: 9th Army]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The Germans were pinning their hopes on the idea that the Soviets might be fended off long enough for the city to be surrendered to the Western Allies.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/> The concentration of Schörner's units went unnoticed by Soviet and Polish reconnaissance.<ref name=zw/>

column1: German forces were composed of elements of the 4th Panzer Army and commanded by the headquarters for the ''Grossdeutschland'' and 57th Armored Corps.  For the battle, the Germans had two armored divisions (the [[20th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)
column3: Hermann Göring]]''), two mechanized divisions (the ''[[Panzergrenadier Division Brandenburg
column5: Hermann Göring 2]]''), an infantry division (the [[17th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)
column6: 17th]]) as well as an infantry division battle group (the remnants of the 545th Volksgrenadier Division).   This force counted some 50,000 soldiers, 300 tanks, and 600 guns.<ref name=Grzelak272/> The supply train of the [[10th SS Panzer Division Frundsberg
column7: 10th SS Panzer Division]] was also present near Bautzen.<ref name=LexikonWehrmacht/>{{Ref label

column1: The Polish Second Army consisted of five infantry divisions: ([[Polish 5th Infantry Division
column6: 10th]], the 1st Armored Corps, and smaller units), about 84,000–90,000 men, and 500 tanks.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Many of them were new recruits inexperienced in combat, incorporated from the recently retaken Polish territories.<ref name=zw/> The quality of the officer corps has also been questioned.<ref name=zw/> One of the major problems facing the People's Army was lack of a qualified cadre; a 1944 estimate showed that the army had one officer for each 1,200 soldiers.<ref name=\"Michta1990\"/> Many of the officers in the Polish Army were Soviet officers of Polish descent.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/>

column1: Overall, the German units were less numerous than the Polish forces, their equipment worn and supplies inferior. Polish sources describe the Germans as more experienced, however the German sources accentuate their mixed structure of experienced soldiers and inexperienced recruits of ''[[Hitlerjugend]]'' and ''[[Volkssturm]]'' units.<ref name=Eberhardt/><ref name=zw/>

column3: Map of the Battle of Bautzen (1)

column3: Map of the Battle of Bautzen (2)

column1: On 21 April, a gap had formed between the Polish infantry units (8th and 9th infantry divisions) and the 1st Armored Corps pushing towards Dresden, and the Polish units which were securing the Muskauer Forst region.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The 7th and 10th infantry divisions were engaged near Neisse and the 5th Infantry Division and the 16th Tank Brigade were in transit in between those two groups.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The Polish units were stretched over a line of {{convert
column4: sp=us}}.<ref name=zw/> The Germans took the opportunity to push into this gap.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The battle started on 21 April.<ref name=\"zw\"/> In the west, the 20th Panzer Division started its drive on Bautzen, while in the east the 17th Infantry Division  advanced on Niesky and Weißenberg, freeing trapped German troops on its way.<ref name=Ahlfen208/> The Germans drove between the Polish Second Army and the [[52nd Army (Soviet Union)
column11: sp=us}} west of Görlitz, sweeping the Soviet units of the [[48th Rifle Corps]], and driving towards [[Spremberg]].<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Major General [[M. K. Puteiko]], commander of the 52nd Army's [[254th Rifle Division]] of the [[73rd Rifle Corps]] was mortally wounded around Bautzen.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998\"/> At first, Polish general Świerczewski continued with his attempt to take Dresden, which contributed to the growing chaos in the Polish forces, as many communication lines were cut.<ref name=zw/>

column1: The Germans succeeded in linking up with the remnants of their forces in the Muskauer Forst, and throwing the local Polish and Soviet forces into chaos.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The Polish Second Army lost cohesion and split into four groups.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Several units of the Polish Second Army found themselves surrounded.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> In particular, the Polish 5th Infantry Division and 16th Tank Brigade were struck in the rear, suffering severe losses.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/> The headquarters of the 5th Division, defended only by sapper and training battalions, came under attack.<ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/> The command group managed to break through to the 16th Tank Brigade, but that unit itself was almost annihilated at [[Förstgen]] (Forsiegen), losing over 90 percent of its personnel; out of 1,300 soldiers, only about 100 survived.<ref name=zw/> The commanding general of the Polish 5th Infantry Division, [[Aleksander Waszkiewicz]], was killed.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-131\"/><ref name=\"MaslovGlantz1998-182\"/> In the village of Niederkaina, today a part of Bautzen, between 196 and 300 captured German members of the ''Volkssturm'' were locked in a barn which was set on fire by retreating Polish or Soviet troops.<ref name=\"Eberhardt\"/><ref name=kiS/><ref name=ba/>

By 23 April the German breakthrough reached the [[Schwarzer Schöps]] River in the east, and [[Lohsa]], [[Oppitz]] and [[Grossdubrau]] in the west. The main body of the German force was located in the forested region around Lohsa.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The Germans continued their push toward [[Königswartha]] and [[Hoyerswerda]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

Eventually, Świerczewski halted his force's advance on Dresden, and ordered it to pull back and secure the breach.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-132\"/> On 22 April he ordered the 1st Armored Corps to change direction, retreat from Dresden and support the centre. The 8th Infantry Division was also recalled; however, the 9th remained near Dresden. For a while Świerczewski was out of communication with his superiors, including Marshal Konev.<ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Konev also sent his chief of staff, General [[Ivan Yefimovich Petrov]], and his chief of operations, General [[Vladimir Ivanovich Kostylev]], to look at the situation.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/> Petrov managed to re-establish communications, and left Kostylev in charge.<ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/> Świerczewski was briefly relieved of his command for incompetence.<ref name=\"zw\"/> To stabilize the situation, Konev ordered eight divisions from the Ukrainian Front to reinforce the Polish positions.<ref name=zw/> The [[14th Guards Rifle Division
column3: 95th Guards Rifle Divisions]], as well as the [[4th Guards Kantemirovskaya Tank Division
column4: 4th Guards Tank Corps]], were ordered to attack toward [[Kamenz]], Königswartha and [[Sdier]] to stop the Germans from advancing further north.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\" /> The [[2nd Air Army]] was also assigned to this theater.<ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/>

column1: Meanwhile, the German advance to the southeast of Bautzen was successful. The Soviet [[294th Rifle Division]] was encircled at Weißenberg by the ''Brandenburg'' Division.<ref name=Ahlfen208/> In its subsequent breakout on 24 April, large parts of the 294th Division were destroyed. At the same time at Bautzen the 20th Panzer Division was able to make contact with the trapped units in the town from the south. Bronikowski then lost no time and immediately ordered an attack into Bautzen. Coordinating with the trapped troops, he was able to break into the town. A hastily assembled Polish counterattack was not successful and most of Bautzen was then recaptured after several days of bloody [[house-to-house fighting
column2: house-to-house combat]]. Several remaining pockets of resistance in the town were cleared during the next days.<ref name=Ahlfen208209/><ref name=B199942-46/> Outside the town the German advance stalled, as their troops were running low on fuel supplies.<ref name=Eberhardt/><ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Bahm2001\"/><ref name=\"Erickson1999\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> The recapture of Bautzen was one of the last successful German tactical victories on the Eastern Front.<ref name=\"WilliamsonAndrew2003\"/>

column1: By 25 April, Polish units were able to stabilize a defense on the line Kamenz–[[Kuckau]]–north Bautzen–Spree–[[Spreewiese]]–[[Kreba-Neudorf
column2: Heideanger]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> On that day, [[Hitler]] congratulated Schörner on his \"victory\".<ref name=\"Mcateer2009\"/> The Polish 7th and 10th infantry divisions were ordered to advance toward Sdier-Heideanger.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> The 7th and 10th Polish infantry divisions slowly advanced, with the 10th reaching north of [[Uhyst
column3: Spreefurt]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> With the Soviet units on their right flank they also secured a road to Königswartha.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/>

column1: The 9th Division found itself alone at the spearhead of the abandoned Polish push towards Dresden. It received orders to retreat on 26 April.<ref name=as/> Attempting to withdraw quickly and to form back with the main forces, it was intercepted by the Germans and sustained heavy losses.<ref name=zw/> The units were moving with insufficient security, on the assumption that the line of retreat was safe; at the same time the Germans captured Polish orders with details of their planned withdrawal routes.<ref name=zw/> Coordination between the units was also lacking.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> 26th Infantry Regiment from the 9th Division took very heavy casualties (75 percent) in the \"valley of death\" around [[Panschwitz-Kuckau]] and [[Crostwitz]].<ref name=zw/> A Polish [[military hospital]] convoy from the same division was ambushed near [[Horka, Saxony
column2: Horka]], with [[War crimes of the Wehrmacht
column3: most of its personnel and wounded executed]] (about 300 casualties). There was only one survivor, chaplain Jan Rdzanek.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"GrzelakStańczyk1993\"/> The division commander, Colonel [[Aleksander Łaski]], was taken captive.<ref name=zw/><ref name=zw/> As a result of these losses, the 9th Division ceased to be an effective force; the remaining personnel were merged into the Soviet [[19th Guards Rifle Division]].<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

column1: According to some sources, 26 April marks the end of this battle, although less severe and isolated clashes in that region continued until 30 April.<ref name=zw/> Other sources note that heavy fighting still took place on 27 April, and that the German advance was only completely halted by 28 April.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> By the end of the month, the Polish Second Army and the Soviet forces had repelled the German attack, forming a line toward Kamenz–[[Doberschütz]]–[[Dauban]], and was preparing to launch an offensive toward [[Prague]].<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/>

Both sides suffered heavy casualties.<ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/> The Polish casualties were particularly severe.<ref name=zw/> In a relatively short time the Polish Second Army lost more than 22 percent of its personnel and 57 percent of its tanks and armored vehicles (about 200 total).<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/> Official estimates claimed about 18,000 casualties (including almost 5,000 dead).<ref name=zw/> Some other estimates give the Polish casualties as up to 25,000.<ref name=zw/> According to Polish historian [[Zbigniew Wawer]], this was the most bloody battle that the [[Polish Army]] had been involved in since the [[battle of Bzura]] in 1939.<ref name=zw/>

German casualties were significant, but less than the Polish and Soviet ones; contemporary Polish sources estimated German losses at 6,500 personnel, which is now seen as an inflated estimate.<ref name=zw/> The German forces failed in their objective of breaking through the 1st Ukrainian Front and coming to the aid of Berlin.<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-138\"/> They managed, however, to inflict very serious casualties on the local Polish and Soviet units and stopped the Polish drive on Dresden (it was still in German hands at the time of the German capitulation on May 9).<ref name=zw/> The successful recapture of Bautzen, Weißenberg and surroundings is called one of the last successful German armored counterattacks of the war. Bautzen and surroundings stayed in German hands until [[German Instrument of Surrender
column2: Germany's capitulation]]. Although the battle had no strategic impact on the battle raging  in Berlin, it allowed most of the participating German units as well as numerous refugees from the east to escape to the west, surrendering to the Western Allies.<ref name=zw/><ref name=B199942-46/><ref name=Ahlfen209/>

column1: Despite the heavy Polish casualties, or possibly because of them, the battle has been largely neglected in Polish [[historiography]].<ref name=\"zw\"/> During the period of the [[People's Republic of Poland]] it was portrayed merely as a difficult but victorious battle.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-134\"/><ref name=\"Komornicki1967-138\"/> However, since the [[fall of communism]] modern Polish historians have been much more critical of Świerczewski's command, blaming his drive on Dresden for the near destruction of the Polish force.<ref name=zw/> Świerczewski's lack of competence, according to some sources, included commanding the battle while drunk.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"Piecuch1997\"/> He was briefly relieved of command by Marshal Konev,<ref name=zw/> but due to the backing of the Soviet high command (most likely the [[NKVD]]) he not only retained his position but all controversies were hushed up, and after the war was hailed as a hero.<ref name=zw/> The actions of other Polish officers have also been questioned, such as the 9th Infantry Division commander's decision to advance without sufficient reconnaissance and escort.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

In modern Poland, the battle's outcome is seen as a victory, if a very costly one, for the Polish and Soviet troops.<ref name=zw/> As noted by historians such as Wawer and Komorowski, despite the heavy casualties, the Polish–Soviet frontline was not seriously breached, and thus the German offensive was a failure.<ref name=zw/><ref name=\"KomorowskiHistorycznych2009\"/>

column4: none}} Wawer incorrectly identifies this formation as the [[5th Guards Tank Army]], which was near the Baltic coast at the time and subordinated to the 2nd Belorussian Front.<ref name=zw/> Komornicki correctly identifies the formation as the [[5th Guards Army (Soviet Union)

none}} Wawer and Solak assert that the 2nd SS Panzer Division was also present in the battle. This is an incorrect assertion as the 2nd SS Division fought in Hungary and Austria from January 1945 until the end of the war.<ref name=T145/> The 21st Panzer Division has also been mentioned in connection with this battle, but the 21st had already moved north as part of reinforcements provided by the 4th Panzer Army to the 9th Army. By the time the Battle of Bautzen had begun, both the 21st Panzer Division and the 10th SS Panzer Division (minus its supply train) were committed to support the 9th Army and both were encircled in the [[Battle of Halbe
column5: Halbe Pocket]]. The assessments of Polish historian Kormonicki,<ref name=\"Komornicki1967-130\"/> German general von Ahlfen, and Polish historian Grzelak all support the order of battle not including the 21st and 10th SS Divisions.

column1: '''U.S. Route 62''' or '''U.S. Highway 62''' ('''US 62''') runs from the [[Mexico-United States border
column2: Mexico-US border]] at [[El Paso, Texas]], to [[Niagara Falls, New York]], near the [[Canada–United States border
column3: Canada–US border]]. It is the only east-west [[United States Numbered Highway]] that connects Mexico and Canada.

column1: Parts of US 62 follow what once was the [[Ozark Trail (road system)
column11: df=mdy-all }}</ref> including the historic bridge across the [[South Canadian River]] in [[Newcastle, Oklahoma]]<ref>{{cite web
column17: date=December 2014}}</ref> (the first structure built with federal highway funds in Oklahoma). This bridge was damaged beyond repair by the [[2013 Moore tornado]] that struck Newcastle and [[Moore, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Historic bridge near Newcastle damaged beyond repair
column21: accessdate=April 11, 2014}}</ref> The highway is signed north–south in New York.

column3: publisher=[[American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials]]

column4: US 62 west of Hobbs, Lea County, [[Eastern New Mexico

column1: US 62 has two separate segments in [[Texas]], separated by a portion in [[New Mexico]] with the first section in Texas from its terminus in El Paso to the state line in the [[Guadalupe Mountains National Park
column2: Guadalupe Mountains]]. Through El Paso, US 62 begins at the [[Paso del Norte International Bridge
column3: Santa Fe Street Bridge]], and follows Santa Fe Street, then Paisano Drive. At the Paisano Drive underpass for [[Interstate 10
column6: US 180]], while US 180 ends its concurrency with I-10. The route then follows Montana Avenue, continuing the concurrency with US 180 until [[Seminole, Texas
column7: Seminole]]. Before exiting Texas, the route passes through the Salt Flats of Texas, the southern base of [[Guadalupe Peak]], the highest point in Texas, and [[Guadalupe Mountains National Park]].

column1: Through New Mexico, US 62 is entirely concurrent with [[U.S. Route 180 in New Mexico
column2: US 180]]. The highway continues past [[Carlsbad Caverns National Park]] and [[White's City, New Mexico
column3: White's City]] into the city of [[Carlsbad, New Mexico
column8: km}}, then heads east to [[Hobbs, New Mexico
column12: km}} of the [[Waste Isolation Pilot Plant
column13: WIPP Plant]] while also coming across several State Highway termini: [[New Mexico State Road 360]] (NM 360), [[New Mexico State Road 176
column23: adj=on}} stretch. US 62 comes into Hobbs along Marland Boulevard. After coming close to [[Hobbs High School]]'s Watson Stadium, US 62 leaves Hobbs going east to the Texas–New Mexico state line.

column1: After re-entering Texas, US 62 continues east through Seminole where US 180 heads east towards [[Lamesa, Texas
column2: Lamesa]] and US 62 turns north northeast along a concurrency with [[U.S. Route 385
column5: Brownfield]]. In Brownfield, US 62 picks up [[U.S. Route 82
column8: Plains]] for a four-way concurrency for about two blocks, where US 380 heads east toward [[Tahoka, Texas
column12: km}} later to head northwest toward [[Levelland, Texas
column13: Levelland]]. US 82 continues as a concurrency with US 62 into [[Lubbock, Texas
column14: Lubbock]]. US 62 splits from US 82 and joins with [[Texas State Highway 114
column18: km}} along the [[Campus of Texas Tech University

column1: <ref>http://www.nysenate.gov/news/new-national-veterans-highway</ref> In 2009, Legislation was proposed in the NY State Legislature for a bill (S.6277-A/A.9939-A) designating all of US Route 62 in New York State as the \"National Veterans Highway\".  The measure was sponsored by then Senator William Stachowski, and Assemblyperson Francine Delmonte as proposed by the Sons of the American Legion Post 880 as a way to salute and commemorate the service and sacrifice of all veterans of the US.  The Bill was signed into law by Governor David Paterson on July 30, 2010.  The designation runs from the Pennsylvania State Line south of Frewsburg, NY to a northern terminus near the Rainbow Bridge in Niagara Falls, NY.  Designations have also been successful in Illinois and Kentucky to this point.
In Ohio, there are plans to reroute US 62 onto a divided highway from Alliance to [[Salem, Ohio
column2: Salem]], part of a larger relocation of both US 62 and [[Ohio State Route 14
column3: SR 14]], then from downtown Youngstown to I-80 as part of the \"Hubbard Arterial\".<ref>[http://www.eastgatecog.org/reg-trac.asp Eastgate Regional Council of Governments: T.R.A.C. Projects]  {{webarchive
column5: date=July 19, 2007 }}</ref> Parts of the highway have long been completed to the north of Alliance and Salem; the portion northwest of Alliance is known in documents as US 62T, while the portion north of Salem not already carrying US 62 is known as SR 14T; neither carries a posted route, instead only carrying [[Route shield
column6: trailblazer markers]] indicating routes intersected at the termini.<ref>[[Ohio Department of Transportation]] [http://www.dot.state.oh.us/techservsite/availpro/Road_%20Infor/SLD/ Straight Line Diagrams] {{Webarchive

column1: US 62 enters New York State from Pennsylvania in [[Chautauqua County, New York
column2: Chautauqua County]], south of [[Frewsburg, New York
column3: Frewsburg]], past which it intersects with [[Interstate 86 (east)
column4: I-86]] (Southern Tier Expressway). Following a northeasterly course, US 62 enters [[Cattaraugus County, New York
column5: Cattaraugus County]], crosses [[Cattaraugus Creek]] to enter [[Erie County, New York
column6: Erie County]] and passes through the village of [[Gowanda, New York
column7: Gowanda]], taking a more northerly direction. At the village of [[Hamburg (village), New York
column8: Hamburg]], US 62 turns northeast, passing Buffalo Raceway and the [[Erie County Fair]], [[New York State Thruway]] ([[Interstate 90
column9: I-90]]), continues northward through [[Lackawanna, New York
column10: Lackawanna]] as South Park Avenue and passes through [[Buffalo, New York
column11: Buffalo]] as South Park Avenue and Bailey Avenue. The Bailey Avenue section from [[New York State Route 5]] (NY 5) at the Buffalo city line to [[New York State Route 324
column12: NY 324]] is maintained by Erie County as County Road 152.

column1: US 62 briefly overlaps NY 324 (Sheridan Drive) in the town of [[Amherst, New York
column2: Amherst]], and turns northward as Niagara Falls Boulevard, intersects [[Interstate 290 (New York)
column3: I-290]], then exits [[Erie County, New York
column4: Erie County]] and enters [[Niagara County, New York
column5: Niagara County]], as US 62 crosses the [[Erie Canal]] / [[Tonawanda Creek]] and travels into the town of [[Wheatfield, New York
column6: Wheatfield]]. The highway intersects [[New York State Route 425
column7: NY 425]] and turns to the northwest intersecting [[New York State Route 265
column9: I-190]]. On the east side of [[Niagara Falls, New York
column10: Niagara Falls]] the route diverges into US 62 and its parallel route, [[U.S. Route 62 Business (Niagara Falls, New York)
column11: Business US 62]], (formerly NY 62A). Within the city of Niagara Falls, US 62 runs \"backwards\", bearing west for several miles as Ferry Avenue southbound (eastbound) and Walnut Avenue northbound (westbound) and terminates on Main Street, while is still signed north–south. The northern (eastern) terminus for both US 62 and Business US 62 is at [[New York State Route 104
column16: Rainbow Bridge]] and U.S. Customs. The Rainbow Bridge then crosses the [[Niagara River]] into Canada, offering side-views of the famous [[Niagara Falls]].

column1: <ref>http://www.nysenate.gov/news/new-national-veterans-highway</ref> In 2009, Legislation was proposed in the NY State Legislature for a bill (S.6277-A/A.9939-A) designating all of US Route 62 in New York State as the \"National Veterans Highway\".  The measure was sponsored by then Senator William Stachowski, and Assemblyperson Francine Delmonte as proposed by the Sons of the American Legion Post 880 as a way to salute and commemorate the service and sacrifice of all veterans of the US.  The Bill was signed into law by Governor David Paterson on July 30, 2010.  The designation runs from the Pennsylvania State Line south of Frewsburg, NY to a northern terminus near the Rainbow Bridge in Niagara Falls, NY.  Designations have also been successful in Illinois and Kentucky to this point.
In Ohio, there are plans to reroute US 62 onto a divided highway from Alliance to [[Salem, Ohio
column2: Salem]], part of a larger relocation of both US 62 and [[Ohio State Route 14
column3: SR 14]], then from downtown Youngstown to I-80 as part of the \"Hubbard Arterial\".<ref>[http://www.eastgatecog.org/reg-trac.asp Eastgate Regional Council of Governments: T.R.A.C. Projects]  {{webarchive
column5: date=July 19, 2007 }}</ref> Parts of the highway have long been completed to the north of Alliance and Salem; the portion northwest of Alliance is known in documents as US 62T, while the portion north of Salem not already carrying US 62 is known as SR 14T; neither carries a posted route, instead only carrying [[Route shield
column6: trailblazer markers]] indicating routes intersected at the termini.<ref>[[Ohio Department of Transportation]] [http://www.dot.state.oh.us/techservsite/availpro/Road_%20Infor/SLD/ Straight Line Diagrams] {{Webarchive
column8: date=February 19, 2003 }} for Columbiana and Mahoning Counties</ref>

column5: [[Swinside]] stone circle, in the [[Lake District]], England, which megalithic specialist [[Aubrey Burl]] called \"the loveliest of all the circles\" in north-western Europe.{{sfn

column1: The '''stone circles in the British Isles and Brittany''' are a [[megalith]]ic tradition of monuments consisting of standing stones arranged in rings. These were constructed from 3300 to 900 BCE in [[Great Britain
column5: p=13}} It has been estimated that around 4,000 of these monuments were originally constructed in this part of north-western Europe during this period.{{sfn
column8: p=13}} Around 1,300 of them are recorded, the others having been destroyed.{{sfn

column1: Although [[stone circles]] have been erected throughout history by a variety of societies and for a variety of reasons, in the [[Late Neolithic]] and [[Bronze Age Britain
column2: Early Bronze Ages]], this particular tradition was limited to Britain, Ireland and the neighbouring area of continental Europe now known as [[Brittany]]. The rings were not distributed equally across this area, but were concentrated in several highland regions: north-eastern and central Scotland, the [[Lake District]], the south-west peninsula of England, and the north and south-west of Ireland. Sparser groupings can also be found in [[Caithness]], the [[Outer Hebrides]], the [[Peak District]], the [[Wicklow Mountains]], [[Wales]] and [[Wessex]].{{sfn

column1: Their original purpose is not fully known, but archaeological investigation has shed some light on it. It is widely thought that they served a ritual or ceremonial purpose, particularly in relation to solar and/or lunar alignments. In a minority of cases, some were also used as cemeteries, with burials being made in and around the circle.

Antiquarian investigation into the circles began in the Early Modern period, intensifying after the publications of notable English antiquarian [[William Stukeley]] in the 18th century. At the time, scholars understood little of prehistoric Britain, with the megalithic circles typically being ascribed either to the [[druid]]s of the [[British Iron Age
column2: Iron Age]] or to the [[Norse activity in the British Isles

column1: In the 20th century, with the development of [[archaeology]], archaeologists could investigate the circles in more detail. They dated them to the Late Neolithic and Bronze Ages. Since the late 20th century, many of these monuments were adopted as \"sacred sites\" by adherents of [[Paganism (contemporary religious movements)
column2: contemporary pagan]] religions such as [[Neo-Druidism]], [[Wicca]] and the [[Goddess movement]], and they had used the sites as places to conduct their magico-religious rites.

column4: The interior of [[West Kennet Long Barrow]]. Long barrows such as this one were the dominant form of megalithic architecture before the development of the stone circle tradition.]]

column1: During the Neolithic, or 'New Stone Age', there were extensive cultural changes across north-western Europe. The introduction of [[agriculture]] ended the [[hunter-gatherer]] lifestyle which had dominated in the preceding Palaeolithic ('Old Stone Age') and Mesolithic ('Middle Stone Age') periods.

During the Early Neolithic in Brittany and the British Isles, the megalithic tradition of building [[chambered tomb]]s for the dead had waxed and waned. The chambered tomb tradition lasted between about 4000 and 3500 BCE, although an earlier example, at [[Carrowmore]] in County Sligo, has been disputably dated to 5000 BCE.<ref name=\"Pearson 2005. p. 34\">[[#Par05
column3: Burl 2000]]. p. 24.</ref> The length of this tradition led prehistorian [[Mike Parker Pearson]] to note that it was \"a relatively short-lived fashion in archaeological terms.\"<ref name=\"Pearson 2005. p. 34\"/> In southern England, 84% of chambered tombs were built in a north-east to south-east orientation, which probably had some special significance for their builders.{{sfn

column1: In some parts of the British Isles, architectural changes were made to the style of chambered tomb, which may have been a forerunner of the later circular design of the stone rings.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 26-27\">[[#Bur00
column2: Burl 2000]]. pp. 26-27.</ref> In the later Clyde tombs of south-western Scotland and the court-cairns of northern Ireland, crescent-shaped forecourts were constructed inside the tombs. This would have enabled more people to enter the tomb and take part in any rites there in sunlight.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 26-27\"/>

column1: During the Early Neolithic another form of monument was also constructed in the British Isles, now known by archaeologists as [[causewayed enclosure]]s.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 25\">[[#Bur00
column2: Burl 2000]]. p. 25.</ref> These  consisted of massive circular ditch-and-bank earthworks. Construction of causewayed enclosures in the lowland regions of Southern England flourished around 3800 BCE, but by 3200 BCE almost all of them had been abandoned by their users.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 25\"/> No equivalents have been found in the highland areas of northern Britain.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 25\"/> Despite having excavated a number of these sites across southern Britain, archaeologists do not know their exact purpose. It has been suggested that they were camps, markets, cattle kraals or occasional settlements, or perhaps ritual centres for the celebration of seasonal festivals or cemeteries.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 25\"/>

Early Neolithic to the Late Neolithic]] took place in around 3000 BCE, there was much economic and technological continuity. But there was considerable change in the style of monuments erected, particularly in southern and eastern England.{{sfn
column5: p=81}} By that date, the [[long barrow]]s, [[causewayed enclosure]]s, and [[cursus]]es which had predominated in the Early Neolithic had ceased to be built. They were replaced by circular monuments of various kinds.{{sfn
column8: p=81}} These include not only stone circles, but also earthen [[henge]]s and [[timber circles]].{{sfn
column11: pp=91–94}} This transition toward circular monuments had symbolic associations. As the archaeologist [[Aubrey Burl]] stated, \"There was a change from the cramped, gloomy chamber of a tomb to the unroofed, wide ring, a change from darkness to light, from the dead to the living, from the grave to the sky.\"{{sfn
column14: p=38}} Similar observations were made by the historian Ronald Hutton, who commented that the circular shape of the rings \"mirrors the sun, the full moon and the bounds of the horizon\" and that such a shape can also be \"profoundly egalitarian\".{{sfn

column4: Alongside the stone circles, earthen henges (such as [[Maumbury Rings]] in Dorset) were erected in Late Neolithic Britain]]

column1: This transition was, according to historian [[Ronald Hutton]], \"as fundamental as that from the Mesolithic had been.\"<ref name=\"Hutton 1991 52\">[[#Hut91
column2: Hutton 1991]]. p. 52.</ref> Archaeological pollen analysis has shown that it was a period when scrub and weeds were spreading over what had formerly been cultivated fields, and forests that had previously been cleared began to grow back.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 29\">[[#Bur00
column3: Burl 2000]]. p. 29.</ref> Chambered tombs were blocked up and abandoned, implying that people were ceasing to use them as cultic sites.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 29\"/> Several former causewayed enclosures were converted into defensive structures with gateways and walls, and in some cases they were attacked. Evidence for conflict has been found at [[Carn Brea, Redruth
column4: Carn Brea]] in Cornwall, [[Hambledon Hill]] in Dorset, and Crickley Hill in Gloucestershire.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 29\"/> Various archaeologists have suggested that this was a period of particular turmoil within the British Isles, perhaps caused by an overuse of land, the failure of crops, famine, plague, climatic change, or an increase in population that was not supported by the food supply.<ref name=\"Burl 2000 29\"/>

column1: The start of the Bronze Age in Britain was signalled by the introduction of [[bronze]], an alloy of [[copper]] and usually [[tin]]. Ideologically, there is no evidence for a change in Brittany and the British Isles at this time, with communities continuing to construct megalithic stone circles. The archaeologists J.M. Coles and A.F. Harding noted that across western Europe, the Bronze Age was \"closely and logically connected\" with the Late Neolithic which preceded it, and that the marker that is applied between the two by contemporary archaeologists is \"arbitrary\".{{sfn

The historian [[Ronald Hutton]] noted that, along with the [[chambered long barrow]]s of the Early Neolithic, stone circles are one of the most prominent forms of monument produced in prehistoric Britain.{{sfn
column4: p=94}} Despite the commonly used term \"stone circles\", many of these monuments are not true circles, but are instead ellipses or ovals.{{sfn
column7: p=91}} The stone circles are not always found in isolation from other forms of monument and often intersect with timber and earth structures.{{sfn
column10: p=132}} For this reason, the archaeologist [[Richard Bradley (archaeologist)
column11: Richard Bradley]] cautioned against understanding stone circles, timber circles, and earthen henges as distinct \"types\" of monument.{{sfn

column1: The archaeologist Alexander Thom suggested that the stone circles fell into four broad classes: circles, flattened circles, egg-shaped rings, and ellipses.{{sfn
Some stone circles, such as that at [[Stanton Drew stone circles
column2: Stanton Drew]] in [[Somerset]], are approached by a short alignment of paired stones.{{sfn
column5: p=123}} There are also stone avenues that link different monuments in the landscape, such as the [[West Kennet Avenue]] which links the Avebury henge to [[The Sanctuary]].{{sfn
column8: p=124}} In some cases, the stone circles survive in such a damaged state that it is not possible to know what they originally looked like.{{sfn

column1: In some examples, timber posts were replaced with stone ones, perhaps with the intention of making the monument more durable and protecting it from decay.{{sfn
column4: p=125}} In others, it is possible that both wooden and stone features of the circle were contemporary with each other.{{sfn

column1: Like henges, the stone circles are almost exclusively found in the British Isles. The distribution of the stone circles is distinctive as it is broader than that of the henges.{{sfn
column4: p=94}} They are found in most areas of Britain where stone is available, except the island's south-eastern corner.{{sfn

column1: They are most densely concentrated in south-western Britain and near [[Aberdeen]].{{sfn
column4: p=94}} There is much diversity in the design of these circles, both between different regions and within them.{{sfn
column7: p=59}} According to Mike Parker Pearson, this is \"perhaps unsurprising for a thousand-year fashion\".{{sfn

column4: [[Long Meg and Her Daughters]], the largest example of Alexander Thom's Type B Flattened Circle]]

column1: The archaeologist and stone circle specialist Aubrey Burl noted that the stone circle builders would have had to undertake \"careful planning\" before they erected these monuments. There was much that they had to take into consideration: the choice of location, the size of the ring, the transport of the heavy stones, the laying out of the circle or ellipse, and the preparation of stone holes. They may have also had to plot astronomical alignments, making the task more difficult.{{sfn

Most stone circles were constructed upon flat ground, although some were instead built on a slope. At some sites, such as [[Kiltierney]] in [[County Fermanagh]], the land was flattened especially for this purpose, although in other cases it is clear that the land had been flattened by earlier communities, who had used the land for settlement or agriculture.{{sfn
Aaron Watson has argued that various circles were located in a particular position to give the appearance of occupying the centre of the world, representing a microcosm of the surrounding area.{{sfn
In some instances it appears that the choice of material used was important.{{sfn
column4: p=126}} For instance, at the [[Ring of Brodgar]] the stones used in the circle were produced from a variety of different sources.{{sfn

column1: Very little is known about the process of quarrying the stone and transporting it to the sites of the circles.{{sfn
column4: p=59}} One exception is at [[Vestra Fiold]] in [[Orkney]], where [[Colin Richards]] led an excavation that determined that the stones used for the Orcadian stone circles were cut from a horizontal seam of bedrock that was located just below the surface.{{sfn
column7: p=59}} These had been eased over a large pit and supported on stone trestles, after which wooden rollers and a sled were likely positioned underneath, allowing the megalith to be moved.{{sfn
column10: p=59}} One of these stones, which weighed over 10 tonnes, had been left in its original position poised on stone supports, to be discovered by the archaeological excavators.{{sfn

column1: Burl noted that archaeologists assumed that for every stone circle that survived to the late 20th century,  there would have been two lost. From the 1300 surviving examples, Burl calculated that there might have originally been around 4000 stone circles across Britain, Ireland and Brittany.{{sfn
Since the 1950s, archaeologists have been able to use [[radiocarbon dating]] of the material around the stones in order to accurately date their original construction.{{sfn
column4: p=13}} As of 2000, the earliest known radiocarbon dating of a stone circle was from the [[Lochmaben Stone]] in [[Dumfriesshire]], which was dated to 2525 ± 85 BCE, whilst the latest examples came from Sandy Road in [[Perth, Scotland
column5: Perth]] (1200 ± 150 BCE), from [[Dromberg]] in [[County Cork]] (790 ± 80 BCE), and from the Five-Stone ring of [[Cashelkeety]] in [[County Kerry]] (715 ± 50 BCE).{{sfn
column8: p=13}} Burl said that, the calibration of these dates indicated that the stone circle tradition existed between 3300 and 900 BCE.{{sfn

column5: Avebury in Wiltshire is the largest example of a stone circle from the British Isles, and is physically situated within an earlier henge.]]

column1: The size of the megalithic rings varied, perhaps according to the number of people who would be using it during ceremonies.{{sfn
column4: pp=44–45}} Burl calculated that the largest stone circle in terms of both diameter and area was [[Stanton Drew stone circles
column5: Stanton Drew]] in Somerset, with a diameter of {{convert
column8: ft}} and an area of 9,887 m² (2.44 acres). Second came the [[Ring of Brodgar]] in Orkney at {{convert
column11: ft}} in diameter and 8,430 m² (2.08 acres) in area, whilst third was [[Avebury]] in Wiltshire, which had a diameter of {{convert
column14: ft}} and an area of 8,236m² (2.04 acres).{{sfn
column17: p=46}} However, Burl did not count the outer stone circle at Avebury, which has a diameter of {{convert
column20: ft}}, making it Britain's largest stone circle. All of the largest circles were found in or near earlier henge monuments.{{sfn
column23: p=45}} Such gargantuan monuments were rare. Burl calculated that most of the megalithic rings (92%) had an average diameter of {{convert
column26: ft}}, with an average area of 150 m² (1615 ft²).{{sfn

column1: The archaeologist [[Alexander Thom]] proposed that the stone circles were built using a unit of measurement which he called the \"[[megalithic yard]]\",{{sfn
column12: p=1}} He came to this conclusion following more than forty years of surveying the monuments, aided by his son Archibald Stevenson Thom.{{sfn

column1: Parker Pearson stated that \"the idea of a standard unit of measurement is very plausible\" but perhaps not as regular as Thom and others have argued.{{sfn
column4: p=59}} In 1980, Burl noted that the idea of Thom's Megalithic Yard \"remain[ed] contentious\".{{sfn

column1: Thom also argued that the builders of these circles were accomplished astronomers and deliberately included astronomical alignments in the rings.{{sfn
According to Parker Pearson, however, many of the circles do not appear to be based on any astronomical alignment.{{sfn
column4: p=59}} Pearson cautioned that Late Neolithic/Bronze Age conceptions of cosmology were likely very different from modern understandings of astronomy.{{sfn
column7: p=59}} However, it has been found that the earliest standing stone monuments in the British Isles, the great circles such as Callanish on the Isle of Lewis and Stenness on the Isle of Orkney, were specifically constructed to align with the sun and moon, and the movements of the sun and moon across the local landscape.<ref>{{Cite journal
column9: title = Origins of Standing Stone Astronomy in Britain: New quantitative techniques for the study of archaeoastronomy
column10: journal = Journal of Archaeological Science: Reports

column5: The largest stone in the King's Men, a stone circle that is the dominant part of the [[Rollright Stones]] complex in the [[Cotswolds]].]]

column1: There has been much analysis and debate about these monuments.{{sfn
column4: p=59}} No simple explanations have emerged.{{sfn
column7: p=59}} The original purposes of the stone ring monuments has been widely debated by antiquarians and archaeologists for several centuries.

column1: These stone circles typically show very little evidence of human visitation during the period immediately following their creation.{{sfn
column4: p=97}} This suggests that they were not sites used for rituals that left archaeologically visible evidence. They may have been deliberately left as \"silent and empty monuments\".{{sfn
column7: p=98}} The archaeologists [[Mike Parker Pearson]] and Ramilsonina suggested that in Neolithic Britain, stone was associated with the dead and wood with the living.{{sfnm
column13: 2pp=97–98}} Bradley noted that this interpretation was \"consistent with the archaeological evidence from Britain\",{{sfn
column16: p=126}} where evidence for feasting and other human activities have been found at a range of timber sites but not at their stone counterparts. At the latter sites, there has been evidence of human remains.{{sfn
column19: p=126}} Bradley suggested that the stone circles may have been spaces \"devoted to the dead\".{{sfn
column22: p=126}} Other archaeologists have suggested that the stone might not represent ancestors, but rather other supernatural entities, such as deities.{{sfn

column1: Aubrey Burl's gazetteer lists 1,303 stone circles in Britain, Ireland and Brittany. The largest number of these are found in Scotland, with 508 sites recorded. There are 316 in England; 187 in Ireland; 156 in Northern Ireland; 81 in Wales; 49 in Brittany; and 6 in the Channel Isles.{{sfn

There are 13 to be found on [[Dartmoor]], including [[Brisworthy stone circle]] and [[Scorhill]], and numerous examples to be found in Cornwall such as [[The Merry Maidens]], [[The Hurlers]] and [[Boscawen-Un]].
In contrast to the over 70 stone circles known from Dartmoor, there are only two known from [[Exmoor]]:{{sfn
column4: p=150}} [[Porlock Stone Circle]] and [[Withypool Stone Circle]].{{sfnm
column14: 3p=1}} The contrast between the number of rings on the two moors may be because Dartmoor has abundant natural [[granite]] while Exmoor has none, instead having [[Devonian]] slates and [[Exmoor Group#Hangman Sandstone Formation
column15: Hangman Grits]], both of which easily break up into small slabs, resulting in a general shortage of big stones on Exmoor.{{sfn
column18: p=150}} The two Exmoor stones are made from smaller stones, which archaeologists have termed ''miniliths''. However, the presence of other Exmoor constructions, such as the [[clapper bridge]] at [[Tarr Steps]] and the three-metre Long Stone at [[Challacombe]], which do use locally sourced large megaliths, suggests that larger stones would have been available had the sites' builders desired, and that the use of miniliths was perhaps deliberate.{{sfn

column1: Wessex contains the two best known, though most atypical stone circles, [[Avebury]] and [[Stonehenge]].{{fact
column2: date=January 2020}} All of the other Wiltshire circles are in a heavily ruined state and in some cases have been destroyed.{{sfn
column5: p=310}} As noted by the archaeologist [[Aubrey Burl]], these examples have left behind \"only frustrating descriptions and vague positions\".{{sfn
column8: p=310}} Most of the known Wiltshire examples were erected on low-lying positions in the landscape.{{sfn

column1: In northern Wiltshire, in the area to the south of [[Swindon]], at least seven stone circles are reported as having existed, often only a few miles distant from one another;{{sfn
column4: p=197}} of these, the [[Day House Lane Stone Circle]] is the only example to survive.{{sfn
column7: p=197}} The stones of the [[Fir Clump Stone Circle]] were for instance removed during construction of the [[M4 motorway]] in 1969.{{sfnm

column4: The Nine Stones near Winterbourne Abbas, Dorset]]

column1: The area of modern Dorset has a \"thin scatter\" of stone circles,{{sfn
column4: p=307}} with nine possible examples known within its boundaries: [[Hampton Down Stone Circle]], [[Kingston Russell Stone Circle]], [[Nine Stones, Winterbourne Abbas
column5: Nine Stones]], and [[Rempstone Stone Circle]] remain visible.{{sfn
column8: p=72}} The archaeologist John Gale described these as \"a small but significant group\" of such monuments.{{sfn
column11: p=72}} All are located within five miles of the sea.{{sfn
column14: p=308}} All but Rempstone—which is on the [[Isle of Purbeck]]—are located on the chalk hills west of [[Dorchester, Dorset
column19: p=138}} The Dorset circles have a simplistic typology, being of comparatively small size, with none exceeding 28 metres in diameter.{{sfnm
column29: 3p=72}} All are oval in shape, although perhaps have been altered from their original form.{{sfnm

column1: With the exception of the sandstone Rempstone circle, all consist of sarsen boulders.{{sfn
column5: p=138}} Much of this may have been obtained from the \"Valley of Stones\", a location at the foot of Crow Hill near to [[Littlebredy]], which is located within the vicinity of many of these circles.{{sfnm
column11: 2pp=182–183}} With the exception of the circle at [[Litton Cheney]], none display evidence of any outlying stones or earthworks around the stone circle.{{sfn
column17: Cecily Piggott]] believed that the circles of Dorset were probably of Bronze Age origin,{{sfn
column21: p=142}} a view endorsed by Burl, who noted that their distribution did not match that of any known Neolithic sites.{{sfn
column24: p=310}} It is possible that they were not all constructed around the same date.{{sfn
column28: p=141}} The Piggotts suggested that while they may well be Early Bronze Age in date, it is also possible that \"their use and possibly their construction may last into the Middle and even into the Late Bronze Age\".{{sfn

column1: Their nearest analogies are the circles found on [[Dartmoor]] and [[Exmoor]] to the west, and the [[Stanton Drew stone circles]] to the north.{{sfn
column5: p=140}} It is also possible that the stone circles were linked to a number of earthen henges erected in Dorset around the same period.{{sfn
column9: p=142}} On average Dorset's earthen henges are four times larger than the stone circles.{{sfn

column1: In what is now northern England, there was a particularly rich stone circle tradition in Cumbria. Several large megalithic rings were constructed here, such as [[Castlerigg stone circle]], [[Swinside]], and [[Long Meg and Her Daughters]].

column3: The Ring of Brodgar, a Neolithic stone circle on [[Orkney]], Scotland.]]

column1: Stone circles exist throughout Scotland, from [[Ninestane Rig]] in the far south to more famous examples in the far north and particularly in the islands (where several form part of a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Sites
column2: World Heritage Site]]). The [[Callanish Stones]] are one of the best-known examples in the [[Outer Hebrides]], while [[Orkney]] is known for its [[Heart of Neolithic Orkney
column3: Neolithic monuments]], including the [[Ring of Brodgar]] and the [[Standing Stones of Stenness]].

column1: In some cases, the stones were removed from the rings for use as a building material.{{sfn
column6: p=3}} In others, the site has been disrupted by natural causes such as trees, the roots of which have shifted the location of the megaliths.{{sfn

column1: Evidence for the destruction of stone circles first comes from the Late Bronze Age.

Following the Christianisation of Britain in the Early Medieval period, various Christian clergyman denounced those pagans who continued to venerate at stones in the landscape, which in some cases perhaps implied stone circles.{{sfn

By the Late Mediaeval period, references to prehistoric monuments in the British Isles were rare, and were usually only to note down practical matters, such as that a judicial court would be held near to one or that a farmer's land lay near to one.{{sfn

A rare exception is found in the fictionalised ''[[History of the Kings of Britain]]'' (c.1136), in which the chronicle's author [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]] claimed that Stonehenge had once been the Giants' Ring, and that it had originally been located on [[Mount Killaraus]] in Ireland, until the wizard [[Merlin]] moved it to Salisbury Plain.{{sfn
Many 19th century antiquarians produced plans of the circles which were \"inaccurate and slipshod.\"{{sfn
In the Mediaeval and Early Modern period onward, much folklore developed around the subject of the stone circles.

In Britain, several stone circles have been connected to the [[countless stones]] motif in folklore. The earliest recorded account comes from [[Philip Sidney]]'s ''The 7 Wonders of England'', written prior to 1586. Sidney linked the motif to Stonehenge.{{sfn
column5: Richard Carew]] mentioned the story in his book, ''The Survey of Cornwall'', published in 1602, noting that it was applied both the Stonehenge and to The Hurlers in Cornwall.{{sfn

column1: The countless stones motif has been attributed to over five different stone circles, as well as several ruined long barrows such as [[Little Kit's Coty House]] in Kent.{{sfn
